7.0 represents the mode, the value that occurs most in the data set (twice, in this case).

B) INCORRECT:

5.5 represents the mean of the data set. This value is obtained by dividing the sum of all the data by the number of values in the data set. When added, the data set in this question will read: 1 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 7 + 7 + 8 + 9 = 44. There are a total of eight values in this data set. Thus, the mean will be → 44 / 8 = 5.5.

C) INCORRECT:

2.73 represents the standard deviation of this data set. This is a measure of the variability of the data points, not a measure of central tendency like the median. Standard deviation is calculated by first summing the squares of the difference between each individual data point and the mean of the data set: (-1.5)2 + (-2.5)2 + (1.5)2 + (-4.5)2 + (1.5)2 + (-0.5)2 + (2.5)2 + (3.5)2 = 52. This value is divided by the total number of values in the data set minus one (8-1=7) to calculate the variance → (52 / 7) = 7.43. Standard deviation is then calculated as the square root of the variance: √7.43 = 2.73.

D) CORRECT:

The median divides the upper half of the data set from the lower half. That is, 50% of the data set lies below the median value and 50% lies above it. When arranged in order of magnitude, the data set in this question will read: 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 7, 8, and 9 (a total of eight values). The median for this even data set will be the average of the two middle values, 5 and 7 → (5 + 7) / 2 = 6.

The median value is not strongly affected by outliers or skewed data.

E) INCORRECT:

8.0 represents the range of the data set. The range is obtained by subtracting the lowest value (Hospital D - 1) from the highest value (Hospital H - 9) of the data set.
questions.hint: The median represents the middle value of the data set when it is arranged by order of magnitude.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying the association between exclusive breastfeeding and body weight in infants. The body weights of 15 exclusively breastfed infants at the age of 6 months are measured. Results are shown:


Patient
Body weight (kg)


1
7.0


2
6.0


3
6.1


4
6.8


5
7.2


6
6.4


7
6.2


8
6.8


9
6.5


10
7.3


11
6.3


12
8.5


13
6.9


14
6.6


15
5.2


One of the computed measures of central tendency is 6.8 kg. Which of the following characteristics is generally true about this measurement?

choices.text: It is the 50th percentile of a set of values.
It is not applicable for qualitative data analysis.
It is resistant to outliers.
Its value only occurs once in a data set.
It is useful to assess the extent of data variability.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The median represents the 50thpercentile of a data set. The mode represents the most frequent observation in a data set, and it is not necessarily correlated with the 50th percentile.

B) INCORRECT:

The only measure of central tendency that can be used in the analysis of qualitative data (i.e., categorical variables) is the mode. Quantitative data can be described by all three measures (i.e., mean, median, mode).

C) CORRECT:

The mode (epidemiology) of a sample does not change due to the presence of outliers, regardless of their magnitude, because it represents the most frequent value in a given sample. This is also true of the median. In contrast, the mean is a measure of central tendency that is sensitive to the presence of outliers.

D) INCORRECT:

The mode represents the most frequently measured value(s) in a given sample. In samples in which each value occurs only once, there is no mode.

E) INCORRECT:

Measures such as the range (statistics), standard deviation, and interquartile range are used to assess the extent of data variability. However, the mode is a measure of central tendency, which provides a point around which data is clustered.
questions.hint: The value of 6.8 represents the mode in this data set.

questions.text: A research group investigates the safety and toxicity profile of a new drug. Data about the length of time from the administration of the drug until the onset of adverse effects is collected for a period of 20 days. Administration of the drug is terminated for any patient experiencing adverse effects. The collected data is shown. Which of the following statements about this data set is most accurate?

choices.text: The data set follows a right-skewed distribution
The data set follows a normal distribution
The median is greater than the mean
The mean and mode are equal
The data set follows a bimodal distribution
The data set follows a left-skewed distribution

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A data set that follows a right-skewed distribution (positively skewed distribution) is clustered on the left side of the scale with a long tail on the right (positive direction of the scale), as seen here. Such a distribution usually has the following inequality between the measures of central tendency: mean > median > mode.
Image Description:

The middle graph shows a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data (bell curve). In such a distribution, all measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) have the same value.

The left graph shows a positive skew (outliers shifting the mean towards higher values), whereas the right graph shows a negative skew (outliers shifting the mean towards lower values).
The median and the mode are more resistant to outliers than the mean. Note that the mode does not change since it represents the most commonly measured value within the data set.

B) INCORRECT:

A data set following a normal distribution would form a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve with a peak located at the center of the distribution. In this case, however, data is clustered on the left side of the scale, and the data set forms an asymmetrical curve with a peak on the left side of the distribution.

C) INCORRECT:

The median is expected to be greater than the mean in data distribution that shows data points clustered on the right side of a histogram with a long tail to the left (negative direction of the scale), unlike what is seen in this histogram. For the data set shown here, the mean is expected to be greater than the median.

D) INCORRECT:

The mean and mode are expected to be equal in a data set that forms a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve with a peak located at the center of the distribution. In the histogram shown here, the mean is greater than the mode.

E) INCORRECT:

A data set following a bimodal distribution would form a histogram with two different peaks, which suggests the existence of two groups within the study population. In this case, however, the histogram shows only one peak on the left side of the data distribution.

F) INCORRECT:

A data set following a left-skewed distribution (negatively skewed distribution) would form an asymmetrical curve, but the data would cluster on the right rather than the left side of the scale, forming a long tail to the left (negative direction of the scale). The histogram shown here follows a different type of distribution.
questions.hint: The histogram shows an asymmetrical distribution with a long tail pointing to the positive direction of the scale.

questions.text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of a new mRNA vaccine in preventing a viral infection. They conducted a pilot phase II study in which participants were randomized to receive either the new vaccine or a placebo vaccine. After one month of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators conclude that the study lacks statistical power because their study design was flawed. Assuming the investigators intended to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following factors most likely contributed to the low statistical power of the study?

choices.text: Large difference between the mean immune responses
Low probability of a type 2 error
Inadequate number of participants in the study
High precision of the tests used to measure the immune response
High probability of a type 1 error

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The difference between the mean immune responses in the study is the effect size. Large effect sizes yield a high rather than a low statistical power.

B) INCORRECT:

The probability of a type 2 error (denoted as “β”), is inversely related to the statistical power of a study. A low β would, therefore, lead to a high rather than low statistical power.

C) CORRECT:

A low sample size leads to a greater variance of the data and increases the type 2 error rate (denoted as “β”). Since β is inversely related to statistical power (1 - β), the higher the β, the lower the statistical power. To increase the statistical power, investigators must decrease β by increasing the sample size in the study and/or making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest.

With pilot studies, low statistical power on post hoc power analysis is a common occurrence. Pilot studies are conducted when the effect size cannot be reliably estimated (e.g., from literature). When designing a pilot study, the power is fixed a priori (usually at a value ≥ 0.80). The study is then performed using a small number of participants (usually 10–50; the exact number depends on the type of study and type of statistical analysis) and the minimum detectable effect size is measured. Based on this information, a sample size that yields adequate power is calculated, and this sample size is used during the main study.

D) INCORRECT:

A test with high precision will reduce the number of random errors in a study. This will narrow the standard deviation of the mean immune response in each arm and increase the statistical power of a study, not decrease it.

E) INCORRECT:

The probability of a type 1 error (denoted as “α”), is inversely related to the type 2 error rate (denoted as “β”). Because β is inversely related to statistical power, a higher α would result in a higher statistical power.

α is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.
questions.hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating the effect of a new oral antidiabetic drug on fasting serum glucose concentration in patients with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus. For his initial hypothesis, he draws blood from 8 patients who have been taking the drug regularly for 2 weeks and measures their fasting serum glucose concentrations. Laboratory studies show:


Patient 1
90 mg/dL


Patient 2
100 mg/dL


Patient 3
102 mg/dL


Patient 4
119 mg/dL


Patient 5
95 mg/dL


Patient 6
105 mg/dL


Patient 7
109 mg/dL


Patient 8
100 mg/dL


Which of the following is the median of these serum glucose concentrations?

choices.text: 100 mg/dL
102.5 mg/dL
101 mg/dL
29 mg/dL
10 mg/dL

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

100 mg/dL is the mode (statistics) of this data set, which is the most common value in the data set.

B) INCORRECT:

102.5 mg/dL is the mean (statistics) of the data set, which is the arithmetic average of the data set: (90 + 100 + 102 + 119 + 95 + 105 + 109 + 100)/8 = 102.5.

C) CORRECT:

To determine the median (statistics), the data set must be arranged in ascending order. The values of this set, in ascending order, are 90, 95, 100, 100, 102, 105, 109, 119. Since there is an even number of values in the set, the median is the average of the two middle values (i.e., (100 + 102)/2 = 101).

D) INCORRECT:

29 mg/dL is the range of this data set, which is the difference between the largest and smallest value in the set and is calculated as 119 – 90 = 29.

E) INCORRECT:

10 mg/dL is the interquartile range of this data set, which is the difference between the 75th and 25th percentile and is calculated as 105 – 95 = 10.
questions.hint: After arranging the data set in ascending order, the median value separates the lower half of the data from the upper half.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a retrospective study on the effects of ivermectin on the treatment of adult patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) during hospitalization. 315 patients are enrolled in the study and categorized further into three treatment groups; the trial period is 3 months. One group receives 6 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, one group receives 12 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, and one control group receives a placebo once daily. The primary endpoint is viral clearance measured as the mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test. The confidence level is set at 95%. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate to compare the results from the different treatment groups?

choices.text: Pearson correlation analysis
Unpaired t-test
Paired t-test
Analysis of variance
Chi-square test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pearson correlation analysis determines the Pearson correlation coefficient, which describes the strength and polarity (positive, negative) of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. In this scenario, there is only one continuous variable (mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test).

B) INCORRECT:

An unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome for no more than two different categorical groups. This study design compares the means of three groups, so an unpaired t-test would not be appropriate. An unpaired t-test could be used, for example, if the study was comparing the time to negative polymerase chain reaction tests (continuous outcome) in the placebo and 6 mg ivermectin groups.

C) INCORRECT:

A paired t-test can be used to compare the means of a continuous outcome (dependent variable) at different points in time in the same sample group. This study compares the continuous outcome (mean results) of 3 categorical groups at the same point in time. A paired t-test could be used, for example, to compare the viral load assessed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction test (a continuous result) in the 6 mg ivermectin group on two different days.

D) CORRECT:

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a parametric test that compares the means of continuous outcomes of ≥ 2 categorical groups. ANOVA can be used to determine whether the difference in the means of the groups is statistically significant. In this study, the investigators are comparing the difference in the means (dependent, continuous variable) between the intervention groups (independent, categorical variable). ANOVA is therefore the most appropriate statistical method.

The difference between an unpaired t-test and an ANOVA test is that an unpaired t-test can only be performed when the independent variable is composed of no more than two categorical groups (e.g., female or male). Whenever there are three or more categories (e.g., 3 mg, 6 mg, and placebo), only an ANOVA can be performed. For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results (under the condition that certain required assumptions around the distribution of data are true for the sample).
Image Description:

For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

A chi-square test is used to compare the distributions of two categorical variables. This study aims to test the relationship of continuous outcomes (dependent variables) between 3 categorical groups (independent variable). The chi-square test could be used, for example, to assess if there is a statistically significant difference between the proportions of participants with a negative polymerase chain reaction test (dependent variable, categorical data, true/not true) on day 5 in the different treatment groups (independent variable, categorical data).
questions.hint: The study compares the different times to a negative polymerase chain reaction test, that is, the difference in means (continuous outcome) of three categorical treatment groups.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with congestive heart failure comes to the office because of a 1-year history of shortness of breath and fatigue. He says that he has to take breaks from his usual daily activities like cooking or cleaning to catch his breath. Six months ago, he was hospitalized for acute decompensation of heart failure and his medication was adjusted. He says that he has had difficulties remembering his medication regimen. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide, spironolactone, and metformin. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting pretibial edema bilaterally. Auscultation of the lungs discloses bibasilar mild crackles. Transthoracic echocardiography shows increased sizes of the left atrium and ventricle, diastolic dysfunction, and a left ventricular ejection fraction of approximately 0.55. The physician has recently read a pharmaceutical advertisement for a new drug for heart failure called MelliFly and considers prescribing this medication to the patient. Based on the pharmaceutical advertisement shown, which of the following statements about MelliFly is most appropriate with regard to this patient?

choices.text: MelliFly should not be prescribed because of potential drug interactions with this patient's other medications
MelliFly should be prescribed to this patient because of its simple dosing regimen
MelliFly should not be prescribed because the advertisement does not feature this patient's clinical syndrome
MelliFly should not be prescribed because its side effect profile is unfavorable for this patient
MelliFly should be prescribed because it effectively lowers this patient's risk of hospitalization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Safety concerns (e.g., potential interactions) should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. Pharmaceutical advertisements typically feature a safety warnings box that includes information about potential drug interactions and important risks, which should be weighed against the potential benefits of the drug. This patient takes a thiazide diuretic, an aldosterone receptor antagonist, and the biguanide metformin, none of which is mentioned in the safety warnings box of the advertisement.

B) INCORRECT:

The simplicity of a treatment regimen should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. This patient has difficulties remembering his regimen and may benefit from a once-daily medication. However, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering the dosing regimen.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a history of congestive heart failure and an ejection fraction (EF) of 55%, which indicates that he has heart failure with preserved EF. The advertisement states that the medicine is targeted at patients with heart failure with reduced EF (i.e., with an EF of < 40%). The medication does not address this patient's specific condition, so it would not be appropriate to prescribe it.

After a clear definition of a patient's problem (e.g., “congestive heart failure with preserved EF, NYHA III”), the goal of prescribing a drug should be determined (e.g., “improvement of dyspnea and fatigue”). This step is followed by a systematic evaluation of all treatment options, including nonpharmacological options. The options can be compared with regard to their safety (e.g., interactions, contraindications), tolerability (e.g., side effect profile), effectiveness (e.g., maximum expected effect on symptoms), price (e.g., monthly costs), and simplicity (e.g., frequency of dosing regimen). Some of this information can be found in pharmaceutical advertisements (e.g., in the safety warnings box), whereas other information does not need to be included (e.g., price). The patient should be provided with information on the chosen treatment, instructions on the use, and potential safety warnings. Finally, the treatment and its effect should be reevaluated on a regular basis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tolerability (e.g., side effects) should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. Pharmaceutical advertisements typically mention the most important side effects, which should be considered in relation to the patient's medical history and preferences. Poor tolerability may outweigh the benefits of a drug. In this patient, the benefits of treatment with the new drug (overall improved outcome of heart failure) would outweigh the risks and relative frequencies of side effects (e.g., hypoglycemia, urinary tract infections). Furthermore, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering its tolerability.

E) INCORRECT:

Effectiveness should be taken into account when prescribing a drug to a patient. The risk of hospitalization for heart failure is effectively lowered by the drug in the advertisement and the results of the study are statistically significant (HR = 0.63, p < 0.001). However, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering its effectiveness for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has heart failure with marked limitations of physical activity (i.e., NYHA class III). When prescribing a medication to a patient, the physician should follow a systematic approach and first consider the patient's individual problem.

questions.text: Which of the following interpretations can be made correctly from the graph on progressive renal disease in the pharmaceutical advertisement (page 2)?

choices.text: The incidence rate of progressive renal disease for both groups increased over the time of the study period
At the end of the study period, more than 50% of patients in the placebo group had developed progressive renal disease compared to less than 50% in the treatment group
The graph should not be used for treatment decisions because cumulative incidence is not sufficient to allow inferences to be made about the risk for an individual patient

At the end of the study period, the risk of having developed progressive renal disease in the treatment group was approximately 1.5% lower than the risk of progressive renal disease in the placebo group
Treatment with MelliFly reduced the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease by 28% over the time of the study period

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The cumulative incidence (displayed on the y-axis) of progressive renal disease increased for both groups over the time of the study period. However, the incidence rate (i.e., the rate at which new cases developed divided by the total time that participants were observed) is not shown. Incidence rate is measured in person-years, whereas cumulative incidence is a proportion.

B) INCORRECT:

The y-axis of this graph shows a maximum value for the cumulative incidence of 0.10 (i.e., 10%). The risk of developing progressive renal disease at the end of the study period is more than 5% in the placebo group and less than 5% in the treatment group.

C) INCORRECT:

Cumulative incidence, the proportion of new cases of a given disease in a specific time period in all individuals at risk of contracting that disease at the start of the period, can be used to estimate an individual's risk of developing a disease. Cumulative incidence does not account for patients lost to follow-up or who are no longer at risk because they already developed the outcome, so this measure tends to underestimate the true rate of new cases. Nevertheless, cumulative incidence provides an estimate that can be used for treatment decisions.

D) CORRECT:

The y-axis displays the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease, which can be used as an estimate of the risk of developing a disease. At the end of the study period, the cumulative incidence (i.e., risk of having developed progressive renal disease) was 0.057 in the placebo group and 0.041 in the treatment group. Therefore, the absolute risk reduction at the end of the study period is: risk in unexposed - risk in exposed = 0.057 - 0.041 = 0.016 (1.6%). Note that in this advertisement, the maximum value of the y-axis is not 1.0 (i.e., 100%), but 0.10 (i.e., 10%). The resulting graph may be misinterpreted and give a false impression of the treatment effect.

In the title above the graph, the advertisement highlights a risk reduction for progressive renal disease of 28%, which is the risk reduction of the treatment group relative to placebo (relative risk reduction: 1 - 0.041 /0.057= 0.28).

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with MelliFly reduced the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease by 28%, but only in relation to the placebo. This difference is the relative risk reduction (RRR = 1 - hazard ratio) and is not equivalent to stating that treatment reduced the cumulative incidence by 28% (absolute risk reduction).
questions.hint: When interpreting a graph, it is important to identify the variables (x-axis and y-axis), the units, and the scaling and maximum values of each axis.

questions.text: A physician is studying the table of treatment effects in the pharmaceutical advertisement in order to find out how she can apply the data from the advertisement to her clinical practice. Which of the following statements about the data on the effects of MelliFly is most appropriate?

choices.text: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus benefit more from treatment with MelliFly than patients without a history of this condition
The confidence intervals of the secondary outcomes should be used with caution when inferring the effects of treatment with MelliFly
Less than 0.1% of patients are hospitalized for heart failure at the end of the study.
The reduction in the incidence of atrial fibrillation under MelliFly in patients who did not have this condition at the beginning of the study is not clinically relevant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the new drug is an SGLT-2 inhibitor and therefore an antidiabetic medication, subgroup analysis showed no difference between major subgroups, which included the diabetic status of the patients.

B) CORRECT:

The confidence intervals for all results without p-values (in this advertisement, all the secondary outcomes) have not been adjusted for multiple comparisons and should therefore only be used with caution when making inferences about the effects of treatment. When several hypotheses are tested simultaneously with one set of data, the high risk of false positives should be mitigated using multiple comparison methods (e.g., Bonferroni correction). If the results are not adjusted, there is a high risk of obtaining one or more significant results solely due to chance. This should be kept in mind when reviewing data from studies or other written material.

C) INCORRECT:

The p-value for the outcome total hospitalizations for heart failure is < 0.001 (0.1%). This does not mean that < 0.1% of patients are hospitalized at the end of the study, but that there is a probability of less than 0.1% that the same or a more extreme result will occur if H0 is true. In other words, if there is actually no difference between the treatment and the placebo group, the same or an even more extreme effect on hospitalizations will be observed in 0.1% of all repetitions of this trial.

D) INCORRECT:

The data from the study suggests that the effect of MelliFly on the incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients who did not have AF at the beginning of the study is not statistically significant (confidence interval for hazard ratio includes 1). However, it is not appropriate to extrapolate clinical relevance from statistical significance. The cut-off for clinical relevance should be determined independently from the statistical significance. For example, it could be determined that every case of AF prevented by Mellifly is clinically relevant because AF prevention reduces the risk of complications (e.g., stroke). The distinction between statistical significance and clinical relevance is even more important in cases in which statistically significant treatment outcomes have little or no clinical significance (e.g., a statistically significant reduction in blood pressure that does not provide any clinical benefit because it lies below a cut-off for clinical relevance of 5 mm Hg).
questions.hint: The pharmaceutical advertisement states that some of the results have not been adjusted for multiple comparisons.

questions.text:
The head of a private urology practice is evaluating the results of a recent patient satisfaction survey. The results indicate that patients consider the time from registration to departure to be too long. The practice identifies the different components of a patient's visit and times how long each one takes. The results are shown:



Registration
Measuring vital parameters
Patient interview
Obtaining blood samples
Scheduling follow-up visits



Mean (min)
4
8
20
8
6


Standard deviation (min)
0.5
5
6
3
2



Optimization of which of the following components is most likely to have the greatest impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit?

choices.text: Registration
Obtaining blood samples
Patient interview
Measuring vital parameters
Scheduling follow-up visits

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Registration has the lowest CV (0.5 ÷ 4 = 0.12). Registration is also the shortest component of the visit, and, therefore, optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining blood samples does not have the highest CV (3 ÷ 8 = 0.38). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient interview is the longest component of the visit with a mean time of 20 minutes. However, the patient interview process does not have the highest CV (6 ÷ 20 = 0.30) and therefore does not have the greatest variation in duration relative to the mean. Some variation in the duration of patient interviews is expected and necessary, as each patient's needs are unique, and care should be personalized accordingly. Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

D) CORRECT:

CV, which is a statistical relative measure of dispersion, allows SD to be interpreted relative to the mean, allowing for the comparison of multiple data sets that may have means of different magnitudes or units of measurement, as CV is dimensionless. A high CV indicates that values are widely spread around the mean. In a system with multiple processes, such as the various aspects of a patient's visit, the process with the highest CV should be optimized first to improve the system's overall reliability and efficiency. Optimization of vital parameter measurements, which has the highest CV (5 ÷ 8 = 0.62), will therefore most likely have the greatest impact on reducing the average time that patients spend in the practice.

In contrast, SD, which is an absolute measure of dispersion, describes the variability of data in relation to the mean within a single data set.

E) INCORRECT:

Scheduling follow-up visits does not have the highest CV (2 ÷ 6 = 0.33). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.
questions.hint: The coefficient of variation (CV) can be used to measure and compare the dispersion around the mean of multiple data sets. CV = standard deviation (SD) ÷ mean.

questions.text: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a new antidiabetic drug in decreasing serum glucose concentration. A total of 500 participants are enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. After 6 months, the mean glucose concentration is 121 mg/dL in the new drug group and 124 mg/dL in the placebo group, with a p-value of 0.02 for the observation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the study result?

choices.text: There is a 2% probability that the observed effect will be seen again if the trial is repeated under similar conditions
The new drug is unlikely to have a clinically significant impact on patient outcome
There is a 98% probability that the new antidiabetic drug is better than placebo
The 95% confidence intervals of each group's serum glucose concentration do not overlap

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H0) is true, there is a 2% probability of obtaining results as extreme or more extreme than those observed on repeated testing. This is not the same as saying that there is a 2% probability of obtaining the observed effect if the study is repeated.

The concept can be understood by flipping a coin twice with the H0 of the coin not being loaded. There are three possible outcomes: two heads (HH), one head and one tail (HT or TH), and two tails (TT) with probabilities of 0.25, 0.5, and 0.25, respectively. If we get the outcome of HH, the p-value for this observation is the probability of obtaining HH plus the sum of the probabilities of outcomes as likely or less likely than HH, which would be 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.5.

B) CORRECT:

The results of a trial are considered clinically significant if they are likely to have a substantial impact on patient outcomes. Although the study shows that the new antidiabetic drug leads to a statistically significant reduction in mean glucose concentration (p < 0.05), this 3 mg/dL decrease is unlikely to benefit patients and have a clinically significant impact on outcomes. Statistical significance and clinical significance do not necessarily correlate. In contrast to statistical significance, there are no predetermined parameters for measuring clinical significance. To estimate the clinical significance of a trial, effect size measures (e.g., Cohen-d, relative risk), impact on patient outcomes, and overall context of the disease, such as prevalence and course (e.g., mortality, morbidity), must be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H0) is true, there is a 2% probability that repeat tests will obtain results at least as extreme as those observed in this test. This does not mean that there is a 98% probability that the alternative hypothesis (H1; that the new antidiabetic drug is better than the placebo) is true.

D) INCORRECT:

If 95% confidence intervals (CIs) do not overlap, there is a statistically significant difference (i.e., the p-value is < 0.05) between the two groups in question. However, the converse statement is not true; a p-value of < 0.05 does not imply that the 95% CIs do not overlap. The 95% CIs can overlap and still result in a p-value of < 0.05.
questions.hint: Implementation of research results in clinical practice requires appropriate interpretation.

questions.text: A group of researchers carries out a retrospective multicenter cohort study to evaluate survival in 4,000 patients aged 65–85 years undergoing either mitral valve repair or replacement to treat mitral valve prolapse. Descriptive analysis shows that 94% of patients in the valve repair group and 83% of patients in the valve replacement group are alive at a 5-year follow-up. The Kaplan-Meier survival analysis shows that the valve replacement group has a hazard ratio for 5-year mortality of 2.31 (95% CI, 2.29–2.33) when compared to the valve repair group. Which of the following is most likely to be the p-value for the hazard ratio?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This p-value is statistically significant because it falls below the study's significance level of 0.05. The value corresponds to a 95% CI that does not include the null value (i.e., a hazard ratio of 1.0, which would indicate that there is no statistically significant difference between the 5-year mortality in the two different cohorts). In addition, the narrow CI in combination with the large sample size of the study indicate that a significant p-value would likely be very small and far below the significance level.

B) INCORRECT:

In this study, the significance level was set at 0.05. Accordingly, a p-value of 0.049 is statistically significant. However, because of the narrow CI and the large sample size, the most likely p-value for the study is expected to be much closer to 0.

C) INCORRECT:

This p-value is greater than the study's significance level of 0.05 and is therefore not statistically significant.

D) INCORRECT:

A p-value of 1 suggests that the findings are purely due to chance. Also, the width of the CI and the size of the p-value are related: the wider the interval, the larger the p-value. This study has a narrow CI, indicating a small p-value.

E) INCORRECT:

The p-value is the probability that the result of a given statistical test will be at least as extreme as the result actually observed, assuming that the null hypothesis is correct. Because it is a probability, the p-value can only be between 0 and 1.
questions.hint: If the 95% confidence interval (CI) of a hazard ratio does not include the value 1.0, the results of the analysis are statistically significant. Confidence intervals and p-values are interrelated.

questions.text:
Question
In patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease, how does ambogliflozin combination therapy (SGLT-2 inhibitor ambogliflozin plus metformin) vs. standard combination therapy (standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin) affect long-term kidney function and glycemic control?
Methods
Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial (Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study). ClinicalTrials.gov FJIM 11001110.
Allocation: Concealed.
Blinding: Double-blinded.
Follow-up period: Up to 5 years.
Setting: 4 veterans care centers in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.
Patients: 300 patients (mean age 65 ± 5.4 years, 95% men) with chronic kidney disease (stage G3–5; eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) and type 2 diabetes receiving a combination regimen with an SGLT-2 inhibitor and metformin. Exclusion criteria were diabetic neuropathy, hemoglobin A1c > 8.5%, and previous kidney transplant. The alpha level was set at 0.05.
Interventions: Ambogliflozin plus metformin (n = 150) vs. standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin (n = 150).
Outcomes: Mean change in eGFR, hemoglobin A1c, systolic blood pressure, and BMI; and incidence of hypoglycemia, diabetic retinopathy, and cardiovascular complications (i.e., stroke and myocardial infarction).
Patient follow-up: 98% (minimum follow-up of 3 years).
Main results
The study found that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a significant improvement in kidney function as measured by eGFR compared to those who received standard combination therapy (mean change from baseline of +2.3 mL/min/1.73 m2 vs. -0.5 mL/min/1.73 m2, p < 0.001). The incidence of diabetic retinopathy was also significantly lower in the ambogliflozin group (7% vs. 12%, RR = 0.6).
Ambogliflozin vs. standard combination therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes

Conclusion
In this study, ambogliflozin combination therapy was more effective than standard combination therapy in improving long-term kidney function and preventing diabetic retinopathy in patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease.

A 68-year-old man with a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. One week ago, he had an ophthalmologist appointment during which he underwent repeat laser photocoagulation for severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. Medical history is also notable for diabetic chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and a stroke 3 years ago. He feels well. Current medications include metformin, empagliflozin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Pulse is 79/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/83 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show an HbA1c of 6.8%, which is at target, and an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m2. Urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 30 mg/g. The patient is a retired military physician who is following recent developments in the pharmaceutical market. He considers a switch from empagliflozin to ambogliflozin therapy. Based on the abstract shown, informing this patient of which of the following effects of the new treatment on his condition is most appropriate?

choices.text: Decreased adverse effects
Slower progression of diabetic retinopathy
No clinically significant benefit
Weight loss
Improved glycemic control

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The most common adverse effects (AEs) of SGLT-2 inhibitors include urinary and genital tract infections, dehydration, weight loss, orthostatic hypotension, and severe diabetic ketoacidosis. However, the incidence of these AEs was not assessed in the study. The only AE assessed was hypoglycemia, and the difference in incidence between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant (i.e., 95% confidence interval of the relative risk includes the null value 1). Other assessed outcomes are more likely to be complications of diabetes than AEs of treatment with an antidiabetic drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the study reports a lower incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy, this patient already has DR. Progression of preexisting DR was not an outcome measure of the study and the potential impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of DR cannot be drawn from the results.

C) CORRECT:

Statistical significance does not necessarily result in clinical significance. In the study, mean change in eGFR over time was statistically significantly higher (p < 0.001) in the ambogliflozin group (+2.3 ± 0.2 mL/min/1.73 m2) than in those who received standard combination therapy (-0.5 ± 0.3 mL/min/1.73 m2). However, while this patient has chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m2 (stage G3 according to the classification of CKD), an increase in eGFR of 2.3 mL/min/1.73 m2 would most likely have no clinically significant benefit on his individual health outcomes. The only other statistically significant result of the trial is decreased incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group compared to those who received standard combination therapy. However, this patient already has DR and further studies would be needed to evaluate the impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of preexisting DR.

D) INCORRECT:

The main results of the clinical trial show that patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy had an average BMI reduction of -3 ± 1 kg/m2 over the study period vs. -1 ± 3 kg/m2 in those who received standard combination therapy. However, this difference was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.5) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's diabetes is already well-controlled at target HbA1c values. Additionally, in the study, the difference in HbA1c levels over time between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.1) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.
questions.hint: When applying study results to patient care, individual patient history should be taken into account to weigh up the most likely benefits and risks.

Which of the following most strongly limits the generalizability of the findings in the study?

choices.text: The statistician performing the analysis was blinded
The allocation was concealed
Patient selection was not representative of the general patient population
A large number of patients were lost to follow-up
The treatment of chronic kidney disease is limited to quaternary care centers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In double-blinded clinical trials, neither the participants nor the researchers know who is in the control group and who is in the treatment group. However, the statistician performing the analysis would not be blinded. The statistician would be blinded in a triple-blinded trial design. In addition, blinding generally reduces biases and increases internal validity in randomized controlled trials, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

B) INCORRECT:

Allocation concealment (blind randomization) is a method used in randomized clinical trials to prevent selection bias. Participants are randomly assigned to either the treatment or the control group using techniques such as centralized randomization schemes and sequentially numbered containers. Concealed allocation is a quality criterion in randomized controlled trials and increases validity, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

C) CORRECT:

Generalizability (external validity) is the applicability of study results to populations other than the study population. A study must be internally valid to have external validity. However, high internal validity does not guarantee external validity. A lack of external validity can arise, for example, if the study population is not representative of the patient population as a whole. This study only included patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes with HbA1c ≤ 8.5% who did not have concomitant diabetic neuropathy or previous kidney transplant. In addition, the study population consisted only of veterans, and 95% of the participants were men. The study population is therefore unlikely to represent the patient population with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease as a whole, which strongly limits generalizability.

D) INCORRECT:

Loss to follow-up can result in attrition bias and can have a significant impact on the internal validity of a study, also limiting its generalizability. However, in this study, only 2% of patients were lost to follow-up.

E) INCORRECT:

The level of care is an indicator of the complexity of medical cases treated. Some therapeutic interventions (e.g., experimental procedures, robot surgery) are only available at quarternary care centers because they must be performed by specialists who only practice in quarternary care centers. Studies using such interventions have limited generalizability because the treatment is often not accessible to the majority of patients. However, chronic kidney disease is a common long-term comorbidity of type 2 diabetes and can be treated by physicians practicing at secondary and tertiary care centers, and SGLT-2 inhibitors are widely available.
questions.hint: To assess whether a study is generalizable, the study population characteristics and set-up of the trial have to be evaluated.

Which of the following conclusions is most appropriate based on the results presented in the table?

choices.text: Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a 10% reduced risk of developing hypoglycemia compared to those who received standard combination therapy
The risk of developing cardiovascular complications in the ambogliflozin group was 10% lower than the risk in those who received standard combination therapy
Patients in the ambogliflozin group were 3 times more likely to lose weight compared to those who received standard combination therapy
Patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy had a 40% reduction in risk of developing diabetic retinopathy compared to patients treated with standard combination therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 20% reduced risk of developing hypoglycemia compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing hypoglycemia was 2% lower in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy than in those who received standard combination therapy (10% vs. 12%, respectively).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a relative risk of developing cardiovascular complications of 0.9 compared to patients who received standard combination therapy. This means that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 10% reduced risk of developing cardiovascular complications compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing cardiovascular complications, on the other hand, was 1% lower in patients in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy (12% vs. 13%, respectively).

C) INCORRECT:

There was no statistically significant difference in mean body mass index (BMI) reduction between the two groups (p-value > alpha level). Additionally, the table reports the crude variation in BMI over time, not the likelihood of losing weight in one arm vs. the other arm of the trial. In order to obtain this information, the investigators would need to fit a linear regression model investigating the association between ambogliflozin combination therapy and BMI reduction over time.

D) CORRECT:

In this study, the incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) has a relative risk (RR) of 0.6 in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy compared to standard combination therapy. The confidence interval does not include the null value of 1 and the results are therefore statistically significant. When results of a study are presented as RR, the corresponding relative risk reduction (if RR < 1) is calculated as follows: % risk reduction = (1 - RR) x 100; relative risk increase (if RR > 1) is calculated as follows: % risk increase = (RR - 1) x 100. In this study, relative risk reduction is (1 - 0.6) x 100 = 40%.

Relative risk reduction should not be confused with absolute risk reduction (ARR), which is calculated as follows: ARR = risk in control group - risk in treatment group. In this study, the ARR for DR would be 12% - 7% = 5%. The risk of developing DR in the ambogliflozin group is therefore 5% lower than the risk of developing DR in the standard combination therapy group.
questions.hint: The outcomes of this study are reported as mean change ± 2 SD with corresponding p-values, and incidence with corresponding relative risk and 95% confidence interval.

questions.text:
Your hospital administration has requested that you review the literature on influenza vaccination in health care workers and update the institution’s vaccination guidelines. As part of your literature review, you identify an old randomized controlled trial in which 100 nursing staff were randomized to receive either a standard dose of a novel seasonal influenza vaccine or placebo. The study showed no statistical difference between the groups in terms of subsequent infection with influenza.
When reviewing the statistical methods, you note that the authors performed a power calculation and report a value of 0.6.
Which one of the following interventions would have increased the power of this study?

choices.text: Increase the sample size
Increase the type II error rate
Increase the variance of the outcome
Reduce the type I error rate
Reduce the difference in the outcome between the novel vaccine and placebo

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Researchers conducting binary-hypothesis studies are at risk for making type I and type II statistical errors.
• A type I error occurs when researchers conclude that a difference exists between two groups when, in fact, no difference exists.
• A type II error occurs when researchers conclude that there is no difference between two groups when, in fact, a difference does exist.
In a study comparing an influenza vaccine with placebo, an example of a type I error would be to conclude that the influenza vaccine reduces the risk of influenza infection when, in fact, it does not reduce this risk. An example of a type II error would be to conclude that the influenza vaccine has no effect on the risk of influenza infection when, in fact, it does reduce this risk.

To reduce the risk of a type II error, researchers ensure that the study has adequate power. The power of a study is the probability that it will detect a difference between two groups that actually are different. Therefore, studies with high statistical power have a good chance of identifying a particular group difference. Depending on the study, a power of at least 0.8 is generally considered necessary; this means that there is an 80% probability that a test of significance will detect a specific difference between two study groups if that difference truly exists.

In general, there are four ways to increase the power of a study:
• Increase the sample size. With a small sample size, the observed difference between the groups can vary noticeably from sample to sample, leading to large standard errors and wide confidence intervals. Increasing the sample size is one approach to reduce the standard error and thus increase power to detect a group difference.
• Decrease the statistical variance. Statistical variance is calculated as the square of the standard deviation and is a measure of the spread of data from the mean. Taking steps to reduce this variance (e.g., by choosing more homogeneous study populations) will ultimately lead to smaller standard errors and increase the likelihood of detecting a difference between those groups if one exists.
• Increase the magnitude of effect between study groups. As the difference in the outcome between two groups increases, it is easier to find a difference between the groups because the distributions in the two groups are farther apart. The larger the difference between the groups’ means and distributions, the greater the power to detect the difference.
• Increase the type I error rate. Allowing for a higher possibility of a type I error increases the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis and therefore reduces the risk of a type II error.

Key learning point: Increasing the sample size of a study will increase the power of that study.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the type I error rate, not the type II error rate, will improve the power of the study.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreasing, not increasing, the statistical variance will improve the power of the study.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing, not reducing, the type I error rate will improve the power of the study.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing, not reducing, the magnitude of effect between study groups will improve the power of the study.

questions.text:
Researchers are studying a novel cancer treatment in patients whose disease is refractory to conventional therapy. The study participants are randomized to one of two arms. Both arms receive the current standard of care; one arm also receives the new therapeutic agent, while the other arm receives placebo. The primary outcome in the study is the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two arms.
Which one of the following scenarios would constitute a type II statistical error in this study?

choices.text: Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS
Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when appropriate hypothesis testing gives a p value of 0.08
Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In this study, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two treatment groups. A type II statistical error would mean that the researchers accepted the null hypothesis when it was actually false; in other words, they concluded that there was no difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was a difference.

A type I error would mean that the researchers rejected the null hypothesis when it was actually true; in other words, they concluded that there was a difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was no difference.

In this study, researchers could reach a correct conclusion by either

• Concluding that there is no PFS difference between the study groups when there truly is none (accepting a true null); or
• Concluding that there is a PFS difference between the two groups when there truly is one (rejecting a false null).

Key learning point: A type II statistical error is defined as acceptance of a null hypothesis that is actually false.

B) INCORRECT:

A type II statistical error would mean that the researchers accepted the null hypothesis when it was actually false; in other words, they concluded that there was no difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was a difference.

C) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there is a difference between the study groups when the p value is >0.05 would not constitute a type I or type II error.

D) INCORRECT:

Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in fact, it is longer with the new drug could occur from misreading the data or if an error occurred during data analysis, but this would not represent a type II error.

E) INCORRECT:

A type II statistical error would mean that the researchers accepted the null hypothesis when it was actually false; in other words, they concluded that there was no difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was a difference.

questions.text:
Researchers are studying a new diet and exercise intervention for weight loss. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms — an intervention arm and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach — and follow them for one year.
At the end of the follow-up period, the average weight loss ± SD (standard deviation) is 14.1 kg ± 5.2 kg for the intervention group and 10.2 kg ± 2.2 kg for the standard-of-care group.
Which one of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?

choices.text: All participants in the standard-of-care group had a weight change between –8.0 kg and +12.4 kg after one year
Given a normal distribution of data, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss between 3.7 kg and 24.5 kg after one year
Weight changes of greater than 2.2 kg or 5.2 kg after one year were considered significant in the standard-of-care and intervention groups, respectively
The maximum amount of weight loss in the intervention group was 19.3 kg after one year
Approximately 5.2% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss greater than the average compared with 2.2% of participants in the standard-of-care group

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

B) CORRECT:

Standard deviation (SD) is a key measure in statistics. It is a measure of dispersion or spread, useful in summarizing continuous data. It describes the spread of a set of data points around a mean value, which is taken as the center point. An SD of zero indicates that all points in the data set are identical and that there is no spread. A small SD indicates that most data points are grouped tightly around the mean; a large SD indicates that the data are spread further from the mean. The spread occurs both above and below the mean. The SD is calculated by first calculating the mean. The mean is subtracted from each sample data set value. Each difference is squared and added together. The total sum is divided by the total number of data set values -1. The square root of this value is the sample SD.

The sample SD, s, is calculated by the following equation,

s = √ ((∑ (xi−x̅)2) / (n - 1)) , where:

• xi = a single value or data point
• x̅ = mean
• n = total number of values in the data set

The SD is widely used in statistics for several purposes. One useful application is to calculate the proportion of observations that occur within a certain range. When observations come from a normal distribution, the range covered by one SD below the mean and one SD above it (x̅ ± 1 SD) includes about 68% of the observations. The corresponding proportion for two SDs (x̅ ± 2 SD) is 95% and for three SDs (x̅ ± 3 SD), 99.7%. In other words, for normally distributed data, 95% of observations would be expected to fall between the two values defined by the mean minus two SDs (x̅ - 2 SD) and the mean plus two SDs (x̅ + 2 SD).

Using the data from the weight-loss study described above, we can determine the range of weight loss experienced by 95% of the participants in the intervention group during one year of follow-up:

• The lower end of the range is found by subtracting two SDs from the mean: 14.1 - 2(5.2) = 3.7 kg.
• The upper end of the range is found by adding two SDs to the mean: 14.1 + 2(5.2) = 24.5 kg.

Therefore, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a one-year weight loss of between 3.7 kg and 24.5 kg.

Key learning point: Standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion or spread of continuous data around a mean value. A small standard deviation indicates that the data points are clustered closely to the mean; a large standard deviation indicates further spread.

C) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

questions.text:
Clinicians at a weight-loss clinic serving late adolescents and young adults are planning to investigate the average BMI of patients at the time they enroll in a program. They randomly select 150 patients and find that the mean BMI of this group was 36.2 at program enrollment. One of the clinicians asks if there is a way to measure whether the mean BMI in this patient sample is a precise measurement of the mean BMI in the larger clinic population.
Which one of the following measures would be most useful to answer this question?

choices.text: Standard error of the mean
Power
P value
Median
Standard deviation of the BMI measurement

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Conducting research on an entire population of interest is rarely feasible, so studies are usually performed on a subset of the total population, called a sample. However, researchers usually want to make inferences from the sample that they can apply to the entire population of interest; in this case, the clinicians want to make an inference about the mean BMI of their clinic population based on their sample. However, the mean BMI of the sample population is probably not identical to the mean BMI of the clinic population; if the clinicians chose other similarly sized samples, they would likely get slightly different mean BMIs. By repeatedly choosing different samples and calculating a sample mean each time, it becomes possible to calculate the standard deviation (SD) of those sample means, which is the standard error of the mean (SEM). The SEM can also be thought of as a measurement of the precision of a sample mean in estimating the population mean.

Fortunately, one does not need to repeatedly choose different samples and calculate individual sample means in order to calculate the SEM. Instead, it is usually calculated by dividing the SD of the measurement (in this case, BMI) by the square root of the sample size (n).

SEM = SD / √n

If either the sample size increases or the SD of the measurement decreases, then the SEM decreases — and our precision increases.

One common use of the SEM is to calculate a 95% confidence interval, using the following equations:

• Lower bound = mean - 1.96 x SEM
• Upper bound = mean + 1.96 x SEM

Key learning point: The measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean is the standard error of the mean.

B) INCORRECT:

The power of a study is the probability that a test of significance will detect an effect that is present. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no power.

C) INCORRECT:

A p value is calculated in hypothesis testing and indicates how incompatible the observed data may be with a null hypothesis. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no p value.

D) INCORRECT:

A median is another measurement of central tendency and can be used instead of a mean in certain circumstances. It represents the middle value of a data set. It does not allow any inferences regarding the population mean.

E) INCORRECT:

The standard deviation (SD) of the BMI measurement is not the only component in assessing whether the sample mean BMI is a precise measurement of the population mean BMI. The SD is an indication of the spread of BMI values around the mean. If there is a wide range of BMI values, then the SD will be large; if there is a narrow range, then the SD will be small. Although the SD is needed to calculate the measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean, it does not (on its own) allow for inferences about the population.

questions.text:
The mother of a 7-year-old boy with recurrent urinary tract infections seeks advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. The relative risk and accompanying 95% confidence interval for each approach are provided:


Approach
Relative risk
95% Confidence interval


A
0.78
0.71–0.86


B
0.74
0.37–0.99


C
0.82
0.75–1.2


D
1.2
1.1–1.4


E
1.3
1.0–1.4


Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect?

choices.text: Approach E
Approach B
Approach A
Approach C
Approach D

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. A confidence interval that does not include 1.0 suggests that there is a likely protective effect of the intervention, while one that does include 1.0 suggests there may be no real difference in outcomes between the treatment and placebo groups.

B) INCORRECT:

An RR estimate greater than or less than 1.0 indicates whether the risk in the treatment group is higher or lower than in the placebo group. A confidence interval that includes 1.0 suggests there may be no real difference in outcomes between the groups. The width of the confidence interval provides information about the precision of the estimate, with a narrower interval indicating more precision.

C) CORRECT:

A relative risk (RR) estimate with a 95% confidence interval provides key information about whether a given intervention is likely to be associated with a given outcome and to what extent. When evaluating an RR estimate and confidence interval, one should ask three key questions:

• Is the RR estimate greater than or less than 1.0?
• Does the confidence interval include 1.0?
• How wide is the confidence interval?

An RR estimate describes the risk of a given outcome in one group compared with the risk in another group. In the scenario described above, the RR equals the risk of recurrence of urinary tract infection (UTI) in the treatment group divided by the risk of recurrence in the placebo group.

• When the treatment group has a lower risk of recurrence than the placebo group (the desired outcome), the RR will be < 1.0.
• When the treatment group has a higher risk of recurrence, the RR will be > 1.0.
• When the treatment and placebo groups have the same risk of recurrence, the RR will equal 1.0.

In addition to the RR estimate itself, one must also consider the 95% confidence interval for the estimate. The confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. For example, if the RR estimate is 0.78 and the 95% confidence interval is 0.71–0.86, then we can be confident that the true RR value lies somewhere between 0.71 and 0.86, which would indicate a likely protective effect of the intervention.

The last piece of information to evaluate when considering an RR estimate is the width of the confidence interval, which provides information about the precision of the estimate. The narrower the confidence interval is, the more precise the RR estimate is. For example, if the RR estimate is 0.78 and the 95% confidence interval was 0.71 to 0.86, that would mean that the intervention likely has a protective effect and the magnitude of that effect (relative reduction in risk) could be anywhere from 14% to 29%.

In this scenario, the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a confidence interval that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest confidence interval) is the RR of 0.78 (confidence interval, 0.71–0.86).

Key learning point: The width of the confidence interval is based on the precision of the estimate. A more precise estimate will have a narrower confidence interval.

D) INCORRECT:

When evaluating an RR estimate and confidence interval, consider if the RR is greater than or less than 1.0, whether the confidence interval includes 1.0, and the width of the confidence interval. A narrow confidence interval indicates a more precise estimate, and an RR < 1.0 with a confidence interval that does not include 1.0 suggests a protective effect of the intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

The width of the confidence interval is based on the precision of the estimate. A more precise estimate will have a narrower confidence interval. An RR estimate describes the risk of a given outcome in one group compared with the risk in another group, and the 95% confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for the true RR.

questions.text:
Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows:



Experimental product
Hypertonic saline
Routine care

P value for difference among the groups


Duration of hospitalization (days)
2.1
1.9
2.2
0.22

1.1

5.2
< 0.001


Cost (dollars per hospital day)
1250
