Clinically significant adverse effects
Vomiting in 4 subjects
Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects
None



What conclusion, if any, can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus infection?

choices.text: Hypertonic saline is the most appropriate intervention
Routine care is the most appropriate intervention
All therapies are equally appropriate
Hypertonic saline and the experimental product are equally appropriate interventions
The experimental product is the most appropriate intervention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

B) CORRECT:

Statistically significant outcome differences in a clinical trial are not necessarily clinically important if the difference between treatment groups is very small, the outcomes studied are not relevant to clinical practice, or both. Analyzing the performance of a specific test or intervention should therefore include relevant parameters, such as adverse effects, costs, psychological impact, quality of life, and burden to individual patients and to society.

In this case, data were complete and available for four outcomes of interest. Of these, routine care was not statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, but was superior in costs and not associated with complications, the more clinically relevant outcomes. Therefore, routine care can be recommended over both the experimental product and hypertonic saline.

Key learning point: Statistical significance in human trials does not necessarily translate into clinical relevance.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive, and hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications, and the experimental product is very expensive.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with moderately severe asthma presents for follow-up. Despite adherence to therapy with an inhaled glucocorticoid and long-acting beta-agonist, she continues to have multiple severe exacerbations requiring hospitalization and systemic glucocorticoid use. You are considering initiation of a novel biologic therapy; however, when you discuss this with the patient and her parents, they mention a family member who suffered a severe rash with this drug.
The drug product monograph notes that severe skin reactions have been reported since the drug was approved, affecting an estimated 1% of patients who receive the drug. You review the primary phase 3 research study, which demonstrated the drug’s efficacy in severe asthma, and note that the researchers enrolled 100 patients in the active-drug arm and another 100 patients to the placebo arm.
What is the probability that at least one severe rash was observed in this study?

choices.text: The probability of detection cannot be determined because adverse events occur randomly

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 10%. The correct probability of detecting at least one adverse event in a study with 100 patients, where the adverse event occurs in 1% of patients, is 63% as calculated using the formula provided.

B) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 100%. The correct probability of detecting at least one adverse event in a study with 100 patients, where the adverse event occurs in 1% of patients, is 63% as calculated using the formula provided.

C) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event in a clinical trial can be estimated using statistical methods. The correct probability of detecting at least one adverse event in a study with 100 patients, where the adverse event occurs in 1% of patients, is 63% as calculated using the formula provided.

D) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 0%. The correct probability of detecting at least one adverse event in a study with 100 patients, where the adverse event occurs in 1% of patients, is 63% as calculated using the formula provided.

E) CORRECT:

Clinical trials are routinely powered with the intention of identifying differences in clinical outcomes between study groups if differences exist. Adverse events from therapeutic interventions must also be reported in these studies; however, rare adverse reactions may be detected only if there are enough study participants to experience them. Therefore, many rare adverse events are reported only in postmarketing studies, when large numbers of patients have been exposed to the therapy in question.

As a general rule, a research team would have to administer a drug to three times as many participants as the frequency of the event to detect that event with 95% confidence. Therefore, if the adverse event occurred in 1 in 100 people (1%), one would need to give the drug to roughly 300 people in order for there to be a 95% likelihood of detecting one event. A more specific formula for the probability of detecting the event is:

1 - (1 - probability of event)number of study participants

To see how to apply this formula in this problem, we note that the probability of the event is 0.01 (1%) and the number of study participants is 100. Plugging those numbers into the formula, we get:

P(at least 1 adverse event) = 1 - (1 - 0.01)100 = 1 - 0.99100 = 1 - 0.366 = 0.634

Therefore, in our example with an adverse reaction occurring in 1% of patients, a study that enrolled 100 patients in the active treatment arm would have a 63% probability of detecting the reaction.

Key learning point: If an adverse drug reaction occurs in 1% of patients, the probability of detecting it in a study with 100 patients receiving the drug is 63%

questions.text:
Researchers are conducting a multisite study to evaluate a new weight-loss intervention among patients aged 11 to 18 with BMIs above the 99th percentile for age. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms — an intervention arm (consisting of a community coach and group exercise program) and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach — and follow them for one year.
At the end of the follow-up period, the average change in weight ± SD (standard deviation) is a loss of 2.3 kg ± 1.1 kg for the intervention group and a gain of 0.7 kg ± 2.3 kg for the standard-of-care group.
Which one of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?

choices.text: Weight changes of greater than 1.1 kg or 2.3 kg after one year were considered significant in the standard-of-care and intervention groups, respectively
Given a normal distribution of data, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss between 0.1 kg and 4.5 kg after one year
Approximately 1.1% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss greater than the average compared with 2.3% of participants in the standard-of-care group
The maximum amount of weight loss in the intervention group was 3.4 kg after one year
All participants in the standard-of-care group had a weight change between –1.6 kg and +3.0 kg after one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

B) CORRECT:

Standard deviation (SD) is a key measure in statistics. It is a measure of dispersion or spread, useful in summarizing continuous data. It describes the spread of a set of data points around a mean value, which is taken as the center point. An SD of zero indicates that all points in the data set are identical and that there is no spread. A small SD indicates that most data points are grouped tightly around the mean; a large SD indicates that the data are spread further from the mean. The spread occurs both above and below the mean.

The sample SD, s, is calculated by the following equation,

s = √ ((∑ (xi−x̅)2) / (n - 1)) , where:

• xi = a single value or data point
• x̅ = mean
• n = total number of values in the data set

The SD is calculated by first calculating the mean. The mean is subtracted from each sample data set value. Each difference is squared and added together. The total sum is divided by the total number of data set values -1. The square root of this value is the sample SD.

The SD is widely used in statistics for several purposes. One useful application is to calculate the proportion of observations that occur within a certain range. When observations come from a normal distribution, the range covered by one SD below the mean and one SD above it (x̅ ± 1 SD) includes about 68% of the observations. The corresponding proportion for two SDs (x̅ ± 2 SD) is 95% and for three SDs (x̅ ± 3 SD), 99.7%. In other words, for normally distributed data, 95% of observations would be expected to fall between the two values defined by the mean minus two SDs (x̅ - 2 SD) and the mean plus two SDs (x̅ + 2 SD).

Using the data from the weight-loss study described above, we can determine the range of weight loss experienced by 95% of the participants in the intervention group during one year of follow-up:

• The lower end of the range is found by subtracting two SDs from the mean: 2.3 - 2(1.1) = 0.1 kg.
• The upper end of the range is found by adding two SDs to the mean: 2.3 + 2(1.1) = 4.5 kg.

Therefore, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a one-year weight loss of between 0.1 kg and 4.5 kg.

Key learning point: Standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion or spread of continuous data around a mean value. A small standard deviation indicates that the data points are clustered closely to the mean; a large standard deviation indicates further spread.

C) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

questions.text: A case-control study is conducted to investigate the association between phenytoin use in pregnant women with epilepsy and congenital malformations in their newborns. The odds ratio of congenital malformations in newborns born to women who were undergoing treatment with phenytoin is 1.74 (P = 0.02) compared to newborns of women who were not treated with phenytoin. Which of the following 95% confidence intervals is most likely reported for this association?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.56–1.88 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.56–1.88. Though this range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74, it also contains the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1) and is, therefore, not statistically significant (i.e., P ≥ 0.05).

B) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.83–2.19 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.83–2.19. Though this range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74, it also contains the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1) and is, therefore, not statistically significant (i.e., P ≥ 0.05).

C) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.36–0.94 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.36–0.94. Though this range does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1), it does not contain the calculated odds ratio of 1.74.

D) CORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 1.34–2.36 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 1.34–2.36 This range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74; in addition, it does not contain an odds ratio of 1 (i.e., the null hypothesis value) and is, therefore, statistically significant (i.e., P < 0.05).

E) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 1.75–2.48 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 1.75–2.48. Though this range does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1), it does not contain the calculated odds ratio of 1.74.
questions.hint: A P value < 0.05 corresponds to a 95% confidence interval that does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1). In this scenario, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the odds of congenital malformations in newborns born to women who received phenytoin compared to those who did not.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The RR estimates the ratio of the probability of an outcome (e.g., recurrence of urinary tract infections) occurring in an exposed group (e.g., those receiving treatment) to the probability of the outcome occurring in an unexposed group (e.g., those receiving placebo). An RR < 1.0 indicates that a given treatment decreases the probability of an outcome. The CI provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. A CI that does not include 1.0 indicates a statistically significant difference between the two groups. Finally, the width of the CI provides information about the precision of the estimate. If the RR estimate is 0.78 and the CI is 0.71–0.86, the intervention likely has a protective effect, and the magnitude of that effect (relative risk reduction) could be anywhere from 14–29%. The narrower the CI, the more precise the RR estimate. Therefore, approach A has the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest CI).

B) INCORRECT:

An RR < 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 suggests a protective effect for this intervention. However, the width of the CI is 0.37–0.99, indicating a relative risk reduction anywhere from 1–63%, which makes this a less precise estimate.

C) INCORRECT:

An RR < 1.0 indicates a protective effect of this intervention. However, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.

D) INCORRECT:

An RR > 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 indicates that this approach increases the risk of urinary tract infections rather than preventing their recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

An RR > 1.0 indicates that the risk of recurrent urinary tract infection in the treatment group is higher than in the placebo group. In addition, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.
questions.hint: When evaluating a relative risk (RR) estimate, consider whether it is greater or less than 1.0. To evaluate a confidence interval (CI), consider whether it includes 1.0 and its width.

questions.text: Researchers are studying a novel cancer treatment in patients whose disease is refractory to conventional therapy. The study participants are randomized to one of two arms. Both arms receive the current standard of care; one arm also receives the new therapeutic agent, while the other arm receives placebo. The primary outcome in the study is the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two arms. Which of the following scenarios would constitute a type 2 error in this study?

choices.text: Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when appropriate hypothesis testing gives a p-value of 0.08
Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS
Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A type 2 error is defined as acceptance of a null hypothesis that is actually false. In this study, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in PFS between the two treatment groups. Therefore, concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in fact, the new drug prolongs PFS constitutes a type 2 error.

B) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there is a difference between the study groups when the p-value is >0.05 would not constitute a type 1 or type 2 error.

C) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there was a difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was no difference constitutes a type 1 error.

D) INCORRECT:

Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in fact, it is longer with the new drug could occur from misreading the data or if an error occurred during data analysis, but this would not represent a type 2 error.

E) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there is no PFS difference between the study groups when there truly is none (i.e., accepting a true null hypothesis) constitutes a correct interpretation of the results.

questions.text: Clinicians at a weight-loss clinic serving late adolescents and young adults are planning to investigate the average BMI of patients at the time they enroll in a program. They randomly select 150 patients and find that the mean BMI of this group was 36.2 at program enrollment. One of the clinicians asks if there is a way to measure whether the mean BMI in this patient sample is a precise measurement of the mean BMI in the larger clinic population. Which of the following measures would be most useful to answer this question?

choices.text: Power
Standard error of the mean
Median
P-value
Standard deviation of the BMI measurement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The power of a study is the probability that a test of significance will detect an effect that is present. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no power.

B) CORRECT:

The standard error of the mean (SEM) is a measure of dispersion used to assess the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean. In this case, the clinicians want to make inferences about the mean BMI of their clinic population based on their random sample. However, the mean BMI of the sample population is likely not identical to the mean BMI of the clinic population; if the clinicians chose other similarly sized samples, they would get slightly different mean BMIs. By repeatedly choosing different samples and calculating a sample mean each time, it becomes possible to calculate the standard deviation (SD) of those sample means, which is the SEM. The SEM can be estimated by dividing the sample SD by the square root of the sample size: SEM = SD / √(sample size). If either the sample size increases or the SD of the measurement decreases, then the SEM decreases and the precision increases.

C) INCORRECT:

A median is another measurement of central tendency and can be used instead of a mean in certain circumstances. It represents the middle value of a data set and does not allow any inferences regarding the population mean.

D) INCORRECT:

A p-value is calculated in hypothesis testing and indicates how incompatible the observed data may be with a null hypothesis. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no p-value.

E) INCORRECT:

The standard deviation (SD) of the BMI measurement is an indication of the spread of the values around the mean. If there is a wide range of BMI values, then the SD will be large; if there is a narrow range, then the SD will be small. Although the SD is needed to calculate the measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean, it does not (on its own) allow for inferences about the population.

questions.text: Researchers are studying a new diet and exercise intervention for weight loss. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms, an intervention arm and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach, and follow them for one year. At the end of the follow-up period, the average weight loss ± SD (standard deviation) is 14.1 kg ± 5.2 kg (31 lb ± 11 lb) for the intervention group and 10.3 kg ± 2.3 kg (23 lb ± 5 lb) for the standard-of-care group. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?

choices.text: The maximum amount of weight loss in the intervention group was 19.3 kg (42 lb) after one year
Given a normal distribution of data, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss between 3.7 kg (9 lb) and 24.5 kg (53 lb) after one year
All participants in the standard-of-care group had a weight change between –8.0 kg (18 lb) and +12.6 kg (28 lb) after one year
Approximately 5.2% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss greater than the average compared with 2.3% of participants in the standard-of-care group
Weight changes of greater than 2.3 kg (5 lb) or 5.2 kg (11 lb) after one year were considered significant in the standard-of-care and intervention groups, respectively

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

B) CORRECT:

In a normal distribution, two SDs above and below the mean cover 95% of the sample. Using the data from the study, we can therefore determine the range of weight loss experienced by 95% of the participants in the intervention group during one year of follow-up. The lower end of the range is found by subtracting two SDs from the mean: 14.1 - 2(5.2) = 3.7 kg (31 - 2(11) = 9 lb). The upper end of the range is found by adding two SDs to the mean: 14.1 + 2(5.2) = 24.5 kg (31 + 2(11) = 53 lb). Hence, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a one-year weight loss of between 3.7 kg and 24.5 kg (9 lb and 53 lb).
Image Description:

Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.

Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.

(SD = standard deviation)

C) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying risk factors for open-angle glaucoma in a group of older patients at a primary care clinic. He wants to assess if patients with diabetes (fasting plasma glucose ≥ 7.0 mmol/L  on two separate readings) are at increased risk of developing open-angle glaucoma compared to patients without diabetes (fasting plasma glucose < 7.0 mmol/L). Which of the following statements best describes the null hypothesis for this study?

choices.text: Improved adherence to antidiabetic medication will not be effective in decreasing the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma.
Diabetes is not associated with an increased prevalence of open-angle glaucoma.
Diabetes does not cause open-angle glaucoma.
The risk of developing open-angle glaucoma is not significantly different in patients with and those without diabetes.
The risk of developing open-angle glaucoma is higher in patients with diabetes than in those without diabetes.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The null hypothesis should relate to the specific variables being tested by the study. In this scenario, the variables are fasting serum glucose measurements (not diabetes medication adherence) and the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma. This option is therefore an inappropriate null hypothesis. Instead, this statement represents an example of a possible interpretation of the results or conclusion drawn from the study.

B) INCORRECT:

This null hypothesis would be more appropriate for a cross-sectional study, which would examine the prevalence of open-angle glaucoma. This study, however, has a cohort design and is examining the incidence of open-angle glaucoma rather than prevalence.

C) INCORRECT:

This study evaluates relative risk, which measures the strength of association between exposure and outcome but does not establish causation. To investigate a possible causal relationship, a regression analysis (e.g., exploring the dose-response relationship) is more appropriate than an association analysis. Even with regression analyses, causal inferences should only be made after careful evaluation of all possible explanations for a result.

D) CORRECT:

The null hypothesis assumes that no statistically significant relationship between the measured variables will be observed in a given study. This study investigates the relationship between an exposure and an outcome. The exposure is the diabetic status of a patient as determined by fasting plasma glucose levels (binary variable: either with or without diabetes). The outcome is the onset of open-angle glaucoma. Association is evaluated using relative risk. Therefore, the null hypothesis for this study is that there is no significant difference in the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma in patients with diabetes compared to those without diabetes.

Key learning point: The null hypothesis posits that there is no statistically significant association between the exposure and the outcome and serves as the starting point that researchers test against to determine if there is evidence supporting an alternative hypothesis.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement represents a possible alternative hypothesis, which attributes the experimental observations to a true effect or relationship between the predictor and outcome variables.
questions.hint: The researcher is planning a prospective cohort study to evaluate the relative risk (RR) of glaucoma in patients with diabetes compared to patients without diabetes. The null hypothesis is RR=1.

questions.text: A data analyst is putting 100 systolic blood pressure values into a spreadsheet for a research study on hypertension during pregnancy. The majority of systolic blood pressure values fall between 130 and 145. For one of the study participants, she accidentally types “1400” instead of “140”. Which of the following statements is most likely to be correct?

choices.text: This is a systematic error.
The mode is now greater than the mean.
The range of the data set is unaffected.
The standard deviation of the data set is decreased.
The median is now smaller than the mean.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systematic errors (bias) are reproducible inaccuracies resulting from an inappropriate experimental design or inaccurate measuring or classification of variables. The accidental inclusion of an outlier is a random error, which can be decreased with repeated measurement or by increasing the sample size.

B) INCORRECT:

On the contrary, the mode is now smaller than the mean. While the mean corresponds to the sum of values divided by the number of values in the set (e.g., (130 + 145 + 1400)/ 3 = 558), the mode is the most frequent value of a data set and thus more resistant to outliers (it lies somewhere between 130 and 145 in this case).

C) INCORRECT:

The range of the data set has increased since it has changed from 130–145 to 130–1400. Outliers result in widening of the range of data.

D) INCORRECT:

On the contrary, measures of precision, such as the standard deviation (SD) and variance (statistics), are increased as a result of this error. SD and variance reflect the spread of data, which becomes wider as a result of outliers.

E) CORRECT:

Typing in a much larger blood pressure reading in relatively small sample sizes will result in a smaller median than mean. While the median is the midpoint of a data set when the values are arranged in ascending order (e.g., 130, 145, 1400; median = 145), the mean corresponds to the sum of the values divided by the number of values in the set (e.g., (130 + 145 + 1400)/ 3 = 558) and is thus particularly susceptible to the influence of outliers.

While in a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data, median, mode, and mean are equal, in a skewed distribution, the mean is shifted in the direction of the skew. In these situations, the median and mode are better at representing the central location of the data, as they are more resistant to outliers.

Key learning point: In a positively skewed distribution, extreme high values pull the mean above the median, which is less affected by outliers.
Image Description:

The middle graph shows a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data (bell curve). In such a distribution, all measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) have the same value.

The left graph shows a positive skew (outliers shifting the mean towards higher values), whereas the right graph shows a negative skew (outliers shifting the mean towards lower values).
The median and the mode are more resistant to outliers than the mean. Note that the mode does not change since it represents the most commonly measured value within the data set.
questions.hint: Typing in a much larger blood pressure reading (an outlier) will result in a positively skewed distribution.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is conducting a summer project with his medical school's pediatrics department using adolescent intelligence quotient (IQ) data from a database of 1,252 patients. He observes that the mean IQ of the dataset is 100. The standard deviation was calculated to be 10. Assuming that the values are normally distributed, approximately 87% of the measurements will fall in between which of the following limits?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This range (statistics) represents 99.7% (3 SD ≅ 30 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.

B) INCORRECT:

This range (statistics) represents 68% (1 SD ≅ 10 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.

C) CORRECT:

This is the only answer option that lies between 1 and 2 standard deviations from the mean. In a normal distribution, approximately 87% of measurements fall within 1.5 SDs from the mean (± 15 IQ points in this case). While knowing this specific value is not necessary, it is important to remember the values for 1 SD (68%), 2 SDs (95%), and 3 SDs (99.7%).

Key learning point: In a normal distribution, approximately 87% of values lie within 1.5 standard deviations of the mean. Standard reference points include 68% (±1 SD), 95% (±2 SD), and 99.7% (±3 SD).
Image Description:

Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.

Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.

(SD = standard deviation)

D) INCORRECT:

This range (statistics) represents 95% (2 SD ≅ 20 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.

E) INCORRECT:

This range (statistics) represents < 50% of IQ measurements (< 1 SD from the mean), but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.
questions.hint: It is not necessary to know the z score to answer this question. Knowing what percentage of values fall within 1 standard deviation (SD), 2 SDs, and 3 SDs of the mean is sufficient to arrive at the right answer.

questions.text: A retrospective cohort study is conducted to assess the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. During chart review, it is found that a history of cesarean birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk (RR) of placenta accreta for patients with a history of cesarean birth is 1.23, with a p-value of 0.03 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.12–1.46. In the context of this study, which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the observed association between cesarean birth and placenta accreta?

choices.text: There is a 95% probability that the true relative risk is higher than 1.12.
There is a 5% probability that the true relative risk is not 1.23.
There is a 95% probability that the true relative risk is between 1.12 and 1.46.
There is a 5% probability that the true relative risk is lower than 1.12.
There is a 3% probability that the observed relative risk of 1.23 is due to chance alone.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The width of a CI (95% in this study) does not indicate the likelihood of the true population value being higher than the lower limit of the interval.

B) INCORRECT:

All statistical tests specify an alpha value, which is a predetermined threshold to measure statistical significance. The alpha value is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when the null hypothesis is true and is usually set at 5%. There is no connection between the alpha value of 5% and the probability of the true population value being different from the observed value, which makes this statement inaccurate.

C) CORRECT:

A CI is a range of values associated with an estimate that is thought to contain the true population value with a given level of confidence. The Cl is determined by the alpha value, which is typically set at 5%, using the following formula: 100% - alpha = Cl. The 95% CI of 1.12–1.46 indicates that there is a 95% probability that the true population RR lies between 1.12 and 1.46. CIs and p-values are interrelated and either can be used to determine whether a result is statistically significant. In this study, the p-value is < 0.05, which corresponds to a 95% CI that does not include the null value (i.e., RR = 1.0), meaning that the null hypothesis can be rejected and the association is therefore considered statistically significant.

Because RR is a ratio and does not follow a normal distribution, the CI is not symmetrical with the observed RR.

Key learning point: A 95% confidence interval indicates a 95% probability that the true population parameter falls within its bounds.

D) INCORRECT:

In a nonnormally distributed sample, the Cl is not symmetrical and does not provide information on the likelihood that the true population value lies outside the Cl bounds. In a normal distribution, 2.5% of values fall below the lower limit of the 95% Cl and 2.5% of values fall above the upper limit of the 95% Cl.

E) INCORRECT:

The p-value is the probability that the result of a given statistical test will be at least as extreme as the result actually observed on repeat testing, assuming that the null hypothesis is true. Accordingly, the p-value of 0.03 in this study signifies that there is a 3% probability that the true population RR is at least as extreme as 1.23, assuming that a prior cesarean birth does not increase the risk of placenta accreta. In this case, if there were no association between prior cesarean birth and placenta accreta (i.e., RR = 1.0) and the study was repeated 100 times, a relative risk of ≥ 1.23 would only be found 3 times (i.e., 3% of the repeated studies). However, this is not equivalent to stating that there is a 3% probability that the RR of 1.23 is due to chance alone.

questions.text: A pediatrician is investigating determinants of childhood obesity. He has been following a cohort of pregnant women with poorly controlled diabetes and comorbid obesity. In the ensuing years, he evaluated the BMI of the cohort's children. The results of the correlation analysis between mean childhood BMI (at 4 years of age) and both mean maternal BMI before pregnancy and mean maternal hemoglobin A1c during pregnancy are shown. All variables are continuous. Based on these findings, which of the following is the best conclusion?

choices.text: There is no association between maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI.
The association between maternal BMI and childhood BMI has a steeper slope than maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI.
Higher maternal HbA1c leads to increased childhood BMI.
There is a positively correlated linear association between maternal BMI and childhood BMI.
Maternal BMI is a stronger predictor of childhood BMI than maternal HbA1c.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An examination of the scatter plot shows that there is a curvilinear (parabolic) relationship between maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI. The correlation coefficient (r) is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. The small and statistically insignificant r coefficient in this scatter plot suggests that there is no linear relationship between the two variables. This does not, however, mean that there is no relationship at all.

B) INCORRECT:

The fact that the r coefficient has larger magnitude for the first scatter plot (r = 0.45 versus r = 0.03) suggests that its data fits a linear relationship better than the second scatter plot. The r coefficient is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. However, it has no bearing on the slope of the line of best fit, which represents the rate of change between the variables and is not shown in these scatter plots.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither the magnitude of the correlation coefficient (r), nor the level of statistical significance (p-value) have any bearing on causality. Correlation does not imply causation.

D) CORRECT:

The correlation coefficient (r) of 0.45 suggests a moderate positive linear correlation between maternal BMI and childhood BMI. An r < 0 implies that there is a negative linear correlation between two variables while an r > 0 implies that there is a positive correlation. The magnitude of the r coefficient represents how closely the data fit a linear relationship (r ranges from -1 to 1; a value of 0.45 is a moderate fit, while a value of 1 would be seen in a perfectly linear positive correlation).

Key learning point: A positive correlation coefficient indicates a direct linear relationship between two continuous variables, with higher values of one variable generally associated with higher values of the other.

E) INCORRECT:

The fact that the correlation coefficient (r) has larger magnitude for the first scatter plot (r = 0.45 versus r = 0.03) suggests that the data fits a linear relationship better than the second scatter plot. Similarly, the smaller p-value (p < 0.01 versus p = 0.23) implies that the linear correlation is statistically significant. However, neither of these values measures the strength of the association between the two variables.
questions.hint: A scatter plot can be helpful in the descriptive analysis of data to show whether there is a type of association. The correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of a linear relationship between two variables (i.e., how close the data points are to a straight line of regression), as well as the polarity of the relationship.

questions.text:
A hematologist has found a historical hemocytometer used during the 1960s. Out of curiosity, he decides to obtain platelet counts from his brother, who has immune thrombocytopenic purpura, with both the historical hemocytometer and a modern automated CBC analyzer. The platelet counts of repeated measurements are shown in ascending order:


Historical hemocytometer
55,000
57,000
62,000
76,000
77,000
82,000
92,000
Mean: 72,000


Modern automated CBC analyzer
71,000
71,000
72,000
72,000
73,000
74,000
74,000
Mean: 72,000


If the measurements on a modern automated CBC analyzer are considered accurate, which of the following conclusions can be drawn about the historical hemocytometer?

choices.text: Test lacks sensitivity.
Test lacks accuracy.
Test lacks specificity.
Test lacks precision.
Test lacks validity.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensitivity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who have a certain disease (e.g., immune thrombocytopenic purpura). No diagnostic threshold is provided to classify results as “positive” or “negative” for ITP in this scenario. Without a defined cutoff value, no conclusions about sensitivity can be drawn.

B) INCORRECT:

Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (platelet counts). A lack of accuracy would probably have resulted in a different mean compared to the modern automated CBC analyzer.

C) INCORRECT:

Specificity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have a certain disease (e.g., immune thrombocytopenic purpura). No diagnostic threshold is provided to classify results as “positive” or “negative” for ITP in this scenario. Without a defined cutoff value, no conclusions about specificity can be drawn.

D) CORRECT:

Based on the results presented, the historical hemocytometer lacks precision (reliability). The test is unreliable, as it does not consistently give similar results on repeated measurements. The range (statistics) of results of the historical hemocytometer is 55,000–92,000, while the range of results of the modern automated CBC analyzer is much smaller (71,000–74,000), indicating that it is more precise. Random errors result in single values differing significantly from the mean during test-retest measurement, which reduces the precision of a test.

Key learning point: Precision (reliability) is reflected by low dispersion in repeated measurements, while wide variability indicates poor precision, regardless of how close the mean is to the true value.
Image Description:

Illustration of the principles of reliability (precision) and validity (accuracy)

The crosses represent data points from repeated measurements taken using the same instrument, and the target represents the true value of the attribute being measured.

Reliability refers to how similar the data points are to each other: when reliability is low, the data points are more widely dispersed. When reliability is high, the data points are more close together.

Validity refers to how close the data points are to the true value: when validity is low, the data points do not approximate the true value.

E) INCORRECT:

Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (platelet counts). A lack of validity would have resulted in a different mean than the modern automated CBC analyzer.
questions.hint: While the mean of the two sets of measurements is the same, the measures of dispersion (e.g., range) are higher with the historical hemocytometer.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study to compare fracture risk in male patients above the age of 65 who received annual DEXA screening to peers who did not receive screening. He conducts a randomized controlled trial in 900 patients, with half of participants assigned to each experimental group. The researcher ultimately finds similar rates of fractures in the two groups. He then notices that he had forgotten to include data from 400 patients in his analysis. Which of the following is most likely to result from including the data of these participants in the analysis?

choices.text: Increased external validity of results.
Decreased probability of seeing a difference between the groups when there truly is no difference.
Increased probability of committing a type II error.
Increased probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis.
Wider confidence intervals of results.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The external validity (i.e., generalizability) of a study refers to how applicable its findings are to the population at large. Although making the study population more representative of the general population may improve its external validity, increasing the sample size would not in itself have a direct effect on it.

B) INCORRECT:

A type I error occurs when a falsely positive result is obtained; a difference between the groups is measured when there is not truly a difference. Every study sets a confidence level (most commonly 0.05) that represents the probability of type I error that the researcher is willing to tolerate. This is a predetermined parameter of the test and would therefore not be affected by increasing the sample size by 400 patients.

C) INCORRECT:

A type II error refers to the probability of obtaining a falsely negative result. Increasing the sample population by 400 patients would result in increased statistical power and therefore lower the probability of a type II error.

D) CORRECT:

Increasing the sample size of the study by including the 400 patients would result in an increased probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true (i.e., increased statistical power). Increased power also leads to a lower likelihood of falsely accepting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true (type II error).

Most studies aim to achieve 80% statistical power (by convention). Power depends mainly on the magnitude of the association (if there is one) and the size of the sample population. If the researchers have an idea of how strong the magnitude of the association is, they can use power calculations to estimate how big a sample population they would need in order to achieve 80% power.

Key learning point: Increasing the sample size enhances statistical power, decreases the risk of type II errors, and narrows confidence intervals, thereby improving the ability to detect true effects.

E) INCORRECT:

The confidence interval of a study is a range that reflects the amount of uncertainty associated with the estimate. It is calculated using the confidence level (by convention, 95%), the standard deviation of the sample, and the number of patients in the sample. Increasing the sample size by including the 400 patients would make the confidence intervals narrower, not wider, indicating more precise results.
questions.hint: Increasing the sample size of a study results in increased statistical power.

questions.text:
A neuro-oncology investigator has recently conducted a randomized controlled trial in which the addition of a novel alkylating agent to radiotherapy was found to prolong survival in comparison to survival radiotherapy alone (hazard ratio = 0.7, p < 0.01). A number of surviving participants who took the alkylating agent reported that they had experienced significant nausea from the medication. The investigator surveyed all participants in both the treatment and the control group on their nausea symptoms by self-report rated mild, moderate, or severe. The investigator subsequently compared the two treatment groups with regard to nausea level.



Mild nausea
Moderate nausea
Severe nausea



Treatment group (%)
20
30
50


Control group (%)
35
35
30



Which of the following statistical methods would be most appropriate to assess the statistical significance of these results?

choices.text: Unpaired t-test.
Chi-square test.
Analysis of variance.
Paired t-test.
Multiple linear regression.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome variable of two categorical groups. Here, the investigator compares the proportions of a categorized outcome variable (nausea level) among two predictor groups (treatment versus control group). Consequently, an unpaired t-test would not be applicable. It could be used, for example, if the investigator was comparing serum glucose levels (a continuous variable) in the two sample populations.

B) CORRECT:

The Chi-square test is ideal for comparing categorical (nominal) variables regardless of the number of subgroups or levels per variable. In this study, the independent categorical variable is treatment with an alkylating agent (versus control). The dependent categorical variable is the nausea category (mild, moderate, and severe). A Chi-square test identifies whether the observations differ significantly from what would be expected by chance and thus tests for statistical significance. The null hypothesis is rejected if there is a statistically significant difference in the proportions of nausea between the two groups.

Key learning point: The chi-square test is the appropriate method to assess whether categorical outcome proportions differ significantly between independent treatment groups.
Image Description:

For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests are used to compare the difference between the means of a continuous outcome variable of two or more categorical groups. The independent variable in this example is two categorical groups (treatment and control). However, the dependent variable is categorical/qualitative (categorized nausea levels), not continuous. Therefore, ANOVA is not the most appropriate significance test. ANOVA could be used, for example, if blood pressure readings were compared between the control and treatment groups.

Note that while ANOVA can technically be used for two categorical groups, an unpaired t-test would be preferred. ANOVA is the preferred test to compare continuous outcomes of three or more categorical groups (e.g., patients who received the alkylating agent, and patients who received a different chemotherapy regimen).

D) INCORRECT:

A paired t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome variable of one predictor group at two points of time. Here, the investigator is comparing the difference between the proportions of a categorized outcome variable (nausea level) among two predictor groups (treatment versus control group). Consequently, a paired t-test would not be applicable. It could be used, for example, if the investigator was comparing serum glucose levels (a continuous variable) at baseline and after 2 months of therapy in the treatment group.

E) INCORRECT:

In multiple linear regression, the relationship between ≥ 2 continuous or categorical predictor variables (i.e., exposure; here: treatment versus control) and a continuous outcome variable (i.e., outcome; here: nausea) is modeled with a line of best fit. Different levels of nausea do not constitute continuous (numeric) data. Multiple linear regression could be used, for example, to evaluate the effects of age, oral drug dosage, and intestinal transit time on serum drug level.
questions.hint: The two variables being compared are the treatment group (alkylating agent versus control) and categorized nausea level (mild, moderate, and severe). In other words, the dependent variable and the independent variable are categorical. Note that percentages do not make a categorical variable continuous.

questions.text: A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89–2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1–2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate?

choices.text: The HR of study B is less likely to be statistically significant than the HR of study A.
The power of study B is likely smaller than the power of study A.
The results of study B are less likely to be accurate than the results of study A.
Study A likely had a larger sample size than study B.
The p-value of study A is likely larger than the p-value of study B.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because the 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0 for study B but includes 1.0 for study A, it can be concluded that the HR for study B is statistically significant, while the HR for study A is not.

B) INCORRECT:

Statistical power is increased by several factors, including large sample size, a large magnitude of effect between groups, increased precision of measurement, and the stringency of the statistical significance criterion chosen for the study (a p-value of 0.03 will fulfill a significance criterion of p < 0.05 before a significance criterion of p < 0.01). Because study B's 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0, this study had sufficient statistical power to detect a difference between the groups. In contrast, study A's 95% confidence interval of the HR includes 1.0; study A is therefore less powerful than study B.

C) INCORRECT:

Accuracy refers to how well a study reflects the truth of the association between the variables of interest. It is impossible to make a statement about this study's accuracy without information regarding its methodology (e.g., inclusion/exclusion criteria, randomization strategy, group demographics), which would allow sources of systematic error to be properly evaluated.

D) INCORRECT:

Assuming that all aspects of study design remain the same, a larger sample size (n) will decrease standard deviation, which results in a narrower confidence interval. Since study B has a narrower confidence interval than study A, it can be inferred that study B in fact had a larger sample size than study A. However, because no other information about the study populations is provided, it cannot be definitively concluded that this is the case.

E) CORRECT:

The 95% confidence interval of the HR for study A includes 1.0 and therefore is not statistically significant (p-value > 0.05). In contrast, the 95% confidence interval of the HR for study B does not include 1.0 and therefore is statistically significant (p-value < 0.05). Although the exact p-values are not given here, we can use this significance criterion to infer that (p-value of study B) < 0.05 < (p-value of study A).

Key learning point: A hazard ratio whose 95% confidence interval includes 1.0 is not statistically significant (p > 0.05).
questions.hint: A hazard ratio (HR) equal to 1.0 means there is no difference in the long-term VTE risk between the rheumatoid arthritis and control groups.

questions.text: A group of environmental health scientists recently performed a nationwide cross-sectional study that investigated the risk of head and neck cancers in patients with a history of cigar and pipe smoking. In collaboration with three teams of epidemiologists that have each conducted similar cross-sectional studies in their respective countries, they have agreed to contribute their data to an international pooled analysis of the relationship between non-cigarette tobacco consumption and prevalence of head and neck cancers. Which of the following statements regarding the pooled analysis in comparison to the individual studies is true?

choices.text: It overcomes limitations in the quality of individual studies.
It is able to provide evidence of causality.
The likelihood of type II errors is decreased.
The level of clinical evidence is lower.
The results are less precise.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The quality of a meta-analysis entirely depends on the individual studies it is composed of. Therefore, the analysis' results are only as valid as the results of each individual study. Merely pooling several studies in itself will not add any benefit in terms of quality.

B) INCORRECT:

Pooling data from various cross-sectional studies may increase the probability that an observed association reaches statistical significance. However, it does not change the fact that observational studies cannot imply causality no matter how strong the statistical power is.

C) CORRECT:

A type II error is the acceptance of the null hypothesis although it is actually false. Increasing sample size by pooling data from several studies translates into increased statistical power, which is the main determinant for type II errors. The higher the statistical power, the higher the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is truly false. Hence, the likelihood of type II error is decreased.

Type I errors are not affected by statistical power as they depend on the significance level.

Key learning point: Increasing the sample size in a meta-analysis enhances statistical power and decreases the risk of type II errors.

D) INCORRECT:

Assuming that each individual contributing study is accurate and valid, a meta-analysis exhibits the highest level of clinical evidence of all study types, even exceeding that of randomized clinical trials or systematic reviews.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing the sample size through pooling not only improves precision and accuracy of the results but also adds the benefit of greater generalizability, and thus more external validity.
questions.hint: The teams are conducting a meta-analysis, which increases statistical power by pooling data across different studies.

questions.text: An investigator is studying determinants of childhood obesity by observing a cohort of pregnant women with obesity. After delivery, he regularly records the height and weight of the cohort's children. The results of the correlation analysis between mean childhood BMI at 4 years of age and mean maternal BMI before pregnancy are shown. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely correlation coefficient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A correlation coefficient (r) of 0 suggests that there is no relationship between the two variables. However, this graph shows a clear trend, where one variable tends to increase as the other variable increases; there does appear to be a relationship between the two variables.

B) INCORRECT:

The correlation coefficient (r) must be positive since the plot is ascending (positive correlation). However, r ranges from -1 to 1; 1.8 is therefore not a meaningful value.

C) INCORRECT:

A correlation coefficient (r) of 0.95 reflects a nearly perfect positive relationship between two variables. As seen in this graph, one variable tends to increase as the other variable increases. While there is clearly a positive trend, the points on the scatter plot do not come close to clustering into a single straight line. This scatter plot suggests that the relationship between the two variables is moderately strong but not the nearly perfect relationship expected with an r of 0.95.

D) INCORRECT:

A correlation coefficient (r) of -0.45 reflects a moderately strong relationship between two variables, which is shown by this scatter plot. However, a negative correlation suggests that one variable tends to decrease as the other increases, which is not the case here.

E) CORRECT:

A correlation coefficient (r) of 0.45 reflects a moderately positive correlation between maternal BMI and childhood BMI. While there is a clear positive trend (i.e., as one variable increases, the other variable also tends to increase), the points on the scatter plot do not cluster into a straight line, indicating that the relationship is moderately strong but not a perfect correlation. Correlation does not imply causation; it merely shows whether a linear relationship exists between the two variables and how strong it is.

The r coefficient is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. However, it has no bearing on the slope of the line of best fit (which is not shown in this scatter plot).

Key learning point: A correlation coefficient (r) of 0.45 signifies a moderate positive relationship, indicating that as one variable increases, the other tends to increase as well, though not in a perfect linear manner.
questions.hint: In the descriptive analysis of data, a scatter plot can be helpful to ascertain whether there is an association between two variables. The correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of the linear relationship between two variables (i.e., how close the data points are to a straight line of regression) as well as the polarity of the relationship.

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to determine the role of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) beta-amyloid levels as a biomarker in the early detection and prognosis of Alzheimer disease. A total of 100 participants are enrolled and separated into three groups according to their Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score: mild dementia (20–24 points), moderate dementia (13–20 points), and severe dementia (< 13 points). Participants' CSF level of beta-amyloid 42 is measured using an immunoassay. The researchers find out that there is a statistically significant difference in CSF levels of beta-amyloid 42 between the groups of dementia severity. Which of the following statistical tests was most likely used to compare the study groups?

choices.text: Pearson correlation analysis.
Chi-square test.
Analysis of variance.
Two-sample t-test.
Fishers exact test.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In Pearson correlation analysis, the Pearson correlation coefficient is determined. The Pearson correlation coefficient describes the strength and polarity (positive, negative) of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. The variables in this scenario include a continuous variable (CSF beta-amyloid 42 levels) and three categorical variables (mild, moderate, and severe dementia), so Pearson correlation analysis is not applicable. The correlation coefficient would be appropriate, for example, to test for a linear relationship between the CSF beta-amyloid 42 levels and the MMSE score (continuous variable ranging from 0–30).

B) INCORRECT:

The Chi-square test compares the distributions of two categorical variables (with ≥ 2 categorical groups per variable). Here, the investigators are comparing the means of a continuous variable (CSF beta-amyloid 42 level) between three categorical groups, so the Chi-square test is not applicable. The Chi-square test could be used, for example, to assess if there is a statistically significant difference in the proportion of individuals with abnormal CSF beta-amyloid 42 levels in the dementia (MMSE ≤ 24) and non-dementia (MMSE > 24) group.

C) CORRECT:

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is the appropriate statistical test in this scenario because it compares differences in means of a continuous variable between ≥ 2 categorical groups (mild, moderate, severe dementia). ANOVA tests the null hypothesis (i.e., there is no difference in means between the groups) by comparing the variation among group means relative to the variation within typically three or more groups. If two or more group means are statistically significantly different from one another, the null hypothesis can be rejected.

Key learning point: ANOVA is used to test whether the means of a continuous outcome variable differ significantly across two or more independent categorical groups, under the null hypothesis that all group means are equal.
Image Description:

For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

A two-sample t-test can be used to determine if there is a statistically significant difference in the means of a continuous variable between two categorical variables (i.e., groups). Here, the investigators are comparing the means of three groups, so a two-sample t-test is not appropriate. A t-test could be used, for example, if the investigators were comparing mean CSF beta-amyloid 42 levels in individuals with (MMSE ≤ 24) and without (MMSE > 24) dementia.

E) INCORRECT:

Fishers exact test is used to determine if there is a statistically significant relationship between two categorical variables (with ≥ 2 categorical groups per variable). Like the Chi-square test, it tests whether the difference between two proportions is statistically significant, but Fishers is usually used when the study sample is small. Here, the investigators are comparing the means of a continuous variable (CSF beta-amyloid 42 level) between three groups, so Fishers exact test is not applicable.
questions.hint: The statistical test was conducted to determine if there are statistically significant differences in the mean of a continuous variable (CSF beta-amyloid 42 level) between three categories of individuals (mild, moderate, and severe dementia).

questions.text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of intranasal ketamine in decreasing acute suicidality in teenagers admitted to inpatient psychiatric units. They conducted a pilot study in which 15 participants were randomized to receive intranasal ketamine while 15 participants were randomized to receive a placebo. The investigators ultimately found no statistically significant difference in suicidality after 30 days of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%. They suspect inadequate statistical power. Assuming the investigators intend to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following changes would be most effective to increase the statistical power?

choices.text: Increase the type I error rate.
Decrease alpha.
Decrease the sample size.
Decrease the type II error rate.
Increase beta.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing the type I error rate (also known as alpha), will have no direct effect on the statistical power. Alpha is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreasing α (otherwise known as the type I error rate) is an aspect of experiment design that is intended to offset the risk of concluding that an effect or difference exists when there is, in fact, no effect or difference. The α is set by the researcher, with the most traditional value being 0.05. These researchers also used 0.05 (i.e., 5%) as the significance threshold. Changing this value will have no direct effect on the statistical power of the experiment.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreasing the sample size will cause a reduction in statistical power. A smaller sample is more subject to the effects of random chance, so the probability of committing a type II error will necessarily increase in this condition.

D) CORRECT:

Decreasing the type II error rate (symbolized as β) reduces the chance of accepting a false null hypothesis and rejecting a viable alternative hypothesis. Reducing β can be achieved by increasing the sample size in the study or by making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest. Either of these two actions will directly increase the statistical power. In mathematical terms, power = 1 – β so it easily follows that reducing β will lead to increased statistical power.

Key learning point: Reducing the probability of a type II error (β) raises statistical power (i.e., the probability that a study will detect a true effect), typically by enlarging the sample size or improving measurement precision.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta, or the probability of a type II error, is the complement of power (power = 1 – β). Increasing β would cause a decrease in statistical power, the opposite of the desired effect.
questions.hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between socioeconomic status and IQ scores. The IQ scores of young American adults have historically been reported to be distributed normally with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. Initially, the researcher obtains a random sampling of 300 high school students from public schools nationwide and conducts IQ tests on all participants. Recently, the researcher received additional funding to enable an increase in sample size to 2,000 participants. Assuming that all other study conditions are held constant, which of the following is most likely to occur as a result of this additional funding?

choices.text: Decrease in standard error of the mean.
Increase in probability of type II error.
Decrease in standard deviation.
Increase in range of the confidence interval.
Increase in risk of systematic error.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The standard error of the mean (SEM) is a measure of the dispersion of a random set of sample means around the true population mean. It is dependent on the variability (i.e., standard deviation) of the measured values (in this case, IQ scores) and the sample size (SEM = SD/√n). By increasing the sample size, the sample means approach the true population mean, resulting in a smaller SEM. In contrast, a greater standard deviation and/or a smaller sample size will increase the SEM, resulting in a less accurate estimate. The SEM is commonly used to calculate confidence intervals that indicate, with a given level of confidence, the range of values within which the true mean of the underlying population falls.

It is important to distinguish between the standard deviation and the SEM. The standard deviation is a measure of the variability of a sample, whereas the SEM is a measure of the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean.

Key learning point: Larger sample sizes lead to a smaller standard error of the mean (SEM = SD/√n), which narrows confidence intervals and enhances the precision of the mean estimate without altering the standard deviation.

B) INCORRECT:

A type II error occurs when the null hypothesis is accepted despite it being false (false-negative error). The probability of type II error (denoted by β) is inversely related to the statistical power of a study (statistical power = 1 - β). Since the statistical power of a study increases with sample size, the probability of type II error will decrease, not increase, under the new study conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

Standard deviation measures the dispersion or spread in data and is an intrinsic property of the population from which the sample is drawn. Increasing the sample size may increase the accuracy of estimating the standard deviation, but it will not change the standard deviation itself.

D) INCORRECT:

An increase in the range of the confidence interval would be expected if there was a decrease in the size of the sample population. The width of the confidence interval is an indicator of the uncertainty in the estimator statistic (in this case, the mean IQ). Smaller study populations are more subject to the effects of chance, leading to less precision in the estimate of the mean which manifests as a wider confidence interval. In contrast, increasing the sample size will mitigate the effects of chance, providing a more precise estimate of the true mean that manifests as a narrower confidence interval (decreased range).

E) INCORRECT:

Systematic error is a form of bias in which a consistent, repeatable error occurs, often due to faulty equipment or flawed study design. A simple example would be trying to estimate the mean body weight of a population using an incorrectly calibrated scale (e.g., one that consistently shows a weight of 3 pounds less than the true weight). A change in sample size would not predispose to this type of error. Random error, on the other hand, is inherent in any sample statistic that estimates a true population parameter. Random error can be reduced by increasing the sample size but systematic error cannot.
questions.hint: Increasing the sample size increases the likelihood that the measured value corresponds to the true mean of the underlying population.

questions.text: A group of investigators conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of rivaroxaban to warfarin for ischemic stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. A total of 14,000 participants were enrolled and one half was assigned to each of the cohorts. The patients were followed prospectively for 3 years. At the conclusion of the trial, the incidence of ischemic stroke in participants taking rivaroxaban was 1.7% compared to 2.2% in participants taking warfarin. The hazard ratio is calculated as 0.79 and the 95% confidence interval is reported as 0.64 to 0.97. If the study was conducted with a total of 7000 participants, which of the following changes would most be expected?

choices.text: Wider confidence interval range.
Decreased type II error rate.
Increased risk of selection bias.
Increased risk of confounding bias.
Decreased type I error rate.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Confidence intervals are defined as the mean ± standard error of the mean, which is calculated by multiplying a Z-score (for 95% confidence intervals this is always 2) by the standard deviation (SD) divided by the square root of the sample size (Mean +/- Z-score (SD/√sample size)). A larger sample size or a decreased SD (based on data precision) will decrease the standard error. Including more disparate data or reducing the sample size, as was done here, will increase the standard error.

Key learning point: Reducing sample size increases the standard error, which in turn widens the confidence interval. Wider intervals reflect less precision in the estimate and decrease the study’s statistical power.

B) INCORRECT:

Type II error is accepting a null hypothesis (disproving alternative hypotheses) when it is actually false. It is measured as 1 - power. When the sample size is reduced, as was done in this case, the power of the study will be reduced. Type II error rate is therefore increased, not decreased.

C) INCORRECT:

Bias is a flaw in a study's methodology that may lead to inaccurate results. Selection bias is the establishment of a sample that is poorly representative of the population or disease being studied, and may therefore skew findings. As this is a methodologic or randomization flaw, the risk of selection bias does not change with the reduced sample size proposed here. It must be managed prior to recruitment.

D) INCORRECT:

Confounding is the ability of an unconsidered variable to influence a relationship being studied (e.g., a study attempting to associate weight with lung cancer incidence may not consider if more overweight patients smoke). This is a methodologic flaw and must be mitigated using subgroup analyses (i.e., looking at smokers who are overweight as their own group), or by performing the same study on multiple populations. A decrease in sample size, as done here, will not change the risk of confounding.

E) INCORRECT:

Type I error rejects the null hypothesis (accepting a different study outcome) when it is in fact true. This value is used to state what threshold should be used to consider the difference between two values as statistically significant. The inverse of type I error is the p-value. This value is fixed regardless of study power, sample size, or standard deviation. Therefore, it would not change if the sample size of this study were reduced.
questions.hint: Decreasing the number of participants (i.e., the sample size) also decreases the power of the study.

questions.text: A research group investigates the safety and toxicity profile of a new drug. Data about the length of time from the administration of the drug until the onset of adverse effects is collected for a period of 20 days. Administration of the drug is terminated for any patient experiencing adverse effects. The collected data is shown. Which of the following statements about this data set is most accurate?

choices.text: The median is greater than the mean.
The data set follows a normal distribution.
The data set follows a left-skewed distribution.
The data set follows a bimodal distribution.
The data set follows a right-skewed distribution.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The median is expected to be greater than the mean in data distribution that shows data points clustered on the right side of a histogram with a long tail to the left (negative direction of the scale), unlike what is seen in this histogram. For the data set shown here, the mean is expected to be greater than the median.

B) INCORRECT:

A data set following a normal distribution would form a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve with a peak located at the center of the distribution. In this case, however, data is clustered on the left side of the scale, and the data set forms an asymmetrical curve with a peak on the left side of the distribution.

C) INCORRECT:

A data set following a left-skewed distribution (negatively skewed distribution) would form an asymmetrical curve, but the data would cluster on the right rather than the left side of the scale, forming a long tail to the left (negative direction of the scale). The histogram shown here follows a different type of distribution.

D) INCORRECT:

A data set following a bimodal distribution would form a histogram with two different peaks, which suggests the existence of two groups within the study population. In this case, however, the histogram shows only one peak on the left side of the data distribution.

E) CORRECT:

A data set that follows a right-skewed distribution (positively skewed distribution) is clustered on the left side of the scale with a long tail on the right (positive direction of the scale), as seen here. Such a distribution usually has the following inequality between the measures of central tendency: mean > median > mode.

Key learning point: A data set with values clustered on the left and a long right tail follows a right-skewed distribution, resulting in mean > median > mode.
Image Description:

The middle graph shows a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data (bell curve). In such a distribution, all measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) have the same value.

The left graph shows a positive skew (outliers shifting the mean towards higher values), whereas the right graph shows a negative skew (outliers shifting the mean towards lower values).
The median and the mode are more resistant to outliers than the mean. Note that the mode does not change since it represents the most commonly measured value within the data set.
questions.hint: The histogram shows an asymmetrical distribution with a long tail pointing to the positive direction of the scale.

questions.text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of a new mRNA vaccine in preventing a viral infection. They conducted a pilot phase II study in which participants were randomized to receive either the new vaccine or a placebo vaccine. After one month of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators conclude that the study lacks statistical power because their study design was flawed.
