Assuming the investigators intended to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following factors most likely contributed to the low statistical power of the study?

choices.text: Large difference between the mean immune responses.
High precision of the tests used to measure the immune response.
High probability of a type 1 error.
Inadequate number of participants in the study.
Low probability of a type 2 error.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The difference between the mean immune responses in the study is the effect size. Large effect sizes yield a high rather than a low statistical power.

B) INCORRECT:

A test with high precision will reduce the number of random errors in a study. This will narrow the standard deviation of the mean immune response in each arm and increase the statistical power of a study, not decrease it.

C) INCORRECT:

The probability of a type I error (α) and the probability of a type II error (β) are inversely related for a fixed sample size: as α increases, β typically decreases. Since statistical power is 1 − β, increasing α generally increases statistical power. However, this trade-off is also influenced by other factors such as sample size and effect size. α is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.

D) CORRECT:

A low sample size leads to a greater variance of the data and increases the type II error rate (denoted as “β”). Since β is inversely related to statistical power (1 - β), the higher the β, the lower the statistical power. To increase the statistical power, investigators must decrease β by increasing the sample size in the study and/or making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest.

With pilot studies, low statistical power on post hoc power analysis is a common occurrence. Pilot studies are conducted when the effect size cannot be reliably estimated (e.g., from literature). When designing a pilot study, the power is fixed a priori (usually at a value ≥ 0.80). The study is then performed using a small number of participants (usually 10–50; the exact number depends on the type of study and type of statistical analysis) and the minimum detectable effect size is measured. Based on this information, a sample size that yields adequate power is calculated, and this sample size is used during the main study.

Key learning point: Low statistical power is most often due to an insufficient sample size, which increases variability and the risk of Type II error. Larger sample sizes reduce error and improve the ability to detect true effects.

E) INCORRECT:

The probability of a type II error (denoted as “β”), is inversely related to the statistical power of a study. A low β would, therefore, lead to a high rather than low statistical power.
questions.hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating the effect of a new oral antidiabetic drug on fasting serum glucose concentration in patients with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus. For his initial hypothesis, he draws blood from 8 patients who have been taking the drug regularly for 2 weeks and measures their fasting serum glucose concentrations. Laboratory studies show:


Patient 1
5 mmol/L


Patient 2
5.55 mmol/L


Patient 3
5.66 mmol/L


Patient 4
6.60 mmol/L


Patient 5
5.27 mmol/L


Patient 6
5.83 mmol/L


Patient 7
6.05 mmol/L


Patient 8
5.55 mmol/L


Which of the following is the median of these serum glucose concentrations?

choices.text: 5.69 mmol/L.
1.60 mmol/L.
5.55 mmol/L.
5.61 mmol/L.
0.56 mmol/L.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

5.69 mmol/L is the mean (statistics) of the data set, which is the arithmetic average of the data set: (5 + 5.55 + 5.66 + 6.60 + 5.27 + 5.83 + 6.05 + 5.55)/8 = 5.69

B) INCORRECT:

1.60 mmol/L is the range of this data set, which is the difference between the largest and smallest value in the set and is calculated as 6.60 – 5 = 1.60.

C) INCORRECT:

5.55 mmol/L is the mode (statistics) of this data set, which is the most common value in the data set.

D) CORRECT:

To determine the median (statistics), the data set must be arranged in ascending order. The values of this set, in ascending order, are 5, 5.27, 5.55, 5.55, 5.66, 5.83, 6.05, 6.60. Since there is an even number of values in the set, the median is the average of the two middle values (i.e., (5.55 + 5.66)/2 = 5.605).

Key learning point: In data sets with an even number of values, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data is arranged in ascending order.

E) INCORRECT:

0.56 mmol/L is the interquartile range of this data set, which is the difference between the 75th and 25th percentile and is calculated as 5.83 – 5.27 = 0.56.
questions.hint: After arranging the data set in ascending order, the median value separates the lower half of the data from the upper half.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a retrospective study on the effects of ivermectin on the treatment of adult patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) during hospitalization. 315 patients are enrolled in the study and categorized further into three treatment groups; the trial period is 3 months. One group receives 6 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, one group receives 12 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, and one control group receives a placebo once daily. The primary endpoint is viral clearance measured as the mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test. The confidence level is set at 95%. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate to compare the results from the different treatment groups?

choices.text: Unpaired t-test.
Paired t-test.
Pearson correlation analysis.
Chi-square test.
Analysis of variance.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome for no more than two different categorical groups. This study design compares the means of three groups, so an unpaired t-test would not be appropriate. An unpaired t-test could be used, for example, if the study was comparing the time to negative polymerase chain reaction tests (continuous outcome) in the placebo and 6 mg ivermectin groups.

B) INCORRECT:

A paired t-test can be used to compare the means of a continuous outcome (dependent variable) at different points in time in the same sample group. This study compares the continuous outcome (mean results) of 3 categorical groups at the same point in time. A paired t-test could be used, for example, to compare the viral load assessed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction test (a continuous result) in the 6 mg ivermectin group on two different days.

C) INCORRECT:

A Pearson correlation analysis determines the Pearson correlation coefficient, which describes the strength and polarity (positive, negative) of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. In this scenario, there is only one continuous variable (mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test).

D) INCORRECT:

A chi-square test is used to compare the distributions of two categorical variables. This study aims to test the relationship of continuous outcomes (dependent variables) between 3 categorical groups (independent variable). The chi-square test could be used, for example, to assess if there is a statistically significant difference between the proportions of participants with a negative polymerase chain reaction test (dependent variable, categorical data, true/not true) on day 5 in the different treatment groups (independent variable, categorical data).

E) CORRECT:

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a parametric test that compares the means of continuous outcomes of ≥ 2 categorical groups. ANOVA can be used to determine whether the difference in the means of the groups is statistically significant. In this study, the investigators are comparing the difference in the means (dependent, continuous variable) between the intervention groups (independent, categorical variable). ANOVA is therefore the most appropriate statistical method.

The difference between an unpaired t-test and an ANOVA test is that an unpaired t-test can only be performed when the independent variable is composed of no more than two categorical groups (e.g., female or male). Whenever there are three or more categories (e.g., 3 mg, 6 mg, and placebo), only an ANOVA can be performed. For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results (under the condition that certain required assumptions around the distribution of data are true for the sample).

Key learning point: Analysis of variance is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome across ≥ 3 independent groups to assess for statistically significant differences.
Image Description:

For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.
questions.hint: The study compares the different times to a negative polymerase chain reaction test, that is, the difference in means (continuous outcome) of three categorical treatment groups.

questions.text: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a new antidiabetic drug in decreasing serum glucose concentration. A total of 500 participants are enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. After 6 months, the mean glucose concentration is 121 mg/dL in the new drug group and 124 mg/dL in the placebo group, with a p-value of 0.02 for the observation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the study result?

choices.text: There is a 2% probability that the observed effect will be seen again if the trial is repeated under similar conditions.
The 95% confidence intervals of each group's serum glucose concentration do not overlap.
The new drug is unlikely to have a clinically significant impact on patient outcome.
There is a 98% probability that the new antidiabetic drug is better than placebo.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H0) is true, there is a 2% probability of obtaining results as extreme or more extreme than those observed on repeated testing. This is not the same as saying that there is a 2% probability of obtaining the observed effect if the study is repeated.

The concept can be understood by flipping a coin twice with the H0 of the coin not being loaded. There are three possible outcomes: two heads (HH), one head and one tail (HT or TH), and two tails (TT) with probabilities of 0.25, 0.5, and 0.25, respectively. If we get the outcome of HH, the p-value for this observation is the probability of obtaining HH plus the sum of the probabilities of outcomes as likely or less likely than HH, which would be 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.5.

B) INCORRECT:

If 95% confidence intervals (CIs) do not overlap, there is a statistically significant difference (i.e., the p-value is < 0.05) between the two groups in question. However, the converse statement is not true; a p-value of < 0.05 does not imply that the 95% CIs do not overlap. The 95% CIs can overlap and still result in a p-value of < 0.05.

C) CORRECT:

The results of a trial are considered clinically significant if they are likely to have a substantial impact on patient outcomes. Although the study shows that the new antidiabetic drug leads to a statistically significant reduction in mean glucose concentration (p < 0.05), this 3 mg/dL decrease is unlikely to benefit patients and have a clinically significant impact on outcomes. Statistical significance and clinical significance do not necessarily correlate. In contrast to statistical significance, there are no predetermined parameters for measuring clinical significance. To estimate the clinical significance of a trial, effect size measures (e.g., Cohen-d, relative risk), impact on patient outcomes, and overall context of the disease, such as prevalence and course (e.g., mortality, morbidity), must be considered.

Key learning point: Statistical significance means results are unlikely due to chance; clinical significance assesses whether the effect size meaningfully improves patient outcomes.

D) INCORRECT:

The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H0) is true, there is a 2% probability that repeat tests will obtain results at least as extreme as those observed in this test. This does not mean that there is a 98% probability that the alternative hypothesis (H1; that the new antidiabetic drug is better than the placebo) is true.
questions.hint: Implementation of research results in clinical practice requires appropriate interpretation.

questions.text: A group of researchers carries out a retrospective multicenter cohort study to evaluate survival in 4,000 patients aged 65–85 years undergoing either mitral valve repair or replacement to treat mitral valve prolapse. Descriptive analysis shows that 94% of patients in the valve repair group and 83% of patients in the valve replacement group are alive at a 5-year follow-up. The Kaplan-Meier survival analysis shows that the valve replacement group has a hazard ratio for 5-year mortality of 2.31 (95% CI, 2.29–2.33) when compared to the valve repair group. Which of the following is most likely to be the p-value for the hazard ratio?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This p-value is statistically significant because it falls below the study's significance level of 0.05. The value corresponds to a 95% CI that does not include the null value (i.e., a hazard ratio of 1.0, which would indicate that there is no statistically significant difference between the 5-year mortality in the two different cohorts). In addition, the narrow CI in combination with the large sample size of the study indicate that a significant p-value would likely be very small and far below the significance level.

Key learning point: A 95% confidence interval for a hazard ratio that excludes 1 indicates statistical significance (p < 0.05), and a very narrow interval, reflecting a large sample, corresponds to an even smaller p-value.

B) INCORRECT:

The p-value is the probability that the result of a given statistical test will be at least as extreme as the result actually observed, assuming that the null hypothesis is correct. Because it is a probability, the p-value can only be between 0 and 1.

C) INCORRECT:

A p-value of 1 suggests that the findings are purely due to chance. Also, the width of the CI and the size of the p-value are related: the wider the interval, the larger the p-value. This study has a narrow CI, indicating a small p-value.

D) INCORRECT:

This p-value is greater than the study's significance level of 0.05 and is therefore not statistically significant.

E) INCORRECT:

In this study, the significance level was set at 0.05. Accordingly, a p-value of 0.049 is statistically significant. However, because of the narrow CI and the large sample size, the most likely p-value for the study is expected to be much closer to 0.
questions.hint: The 95% confidence interval (CI) of the hazard ratio does not include the value 1.0.

questions.text:
Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows:



Experimental product
Hypertonic saline
Routine care

P value for difference among the groups


Duration of hospitalization (days)
2.1
1.9
2.2
0.22


Time to sterilization of nasal passages (days)
1.1
4.3
5.2
< 0.001


Cost (dollars per hospital day)
1250
25
5
< 0.001


Clinically significant adverse effects
Vomiting in 4 subjects
Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects
None



Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with RSV infection?

choices.text: Hypertonic saline and the experimental product are equally appropriate interventions.
Routine care is the most appropriate intervention.
Hypertonic saline is the most appropriate intervention.
All therapies are equally appropriate.
The experimental product is the most appropriate intervention.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications, and the experimental product is very expensive.

B) CORRECT:

Statistically significant outcome differences in a clinical trial are not necessarily clinically important if the difference between treatment groups is very small, the outcomes studied are not relevant to clinical practice, or both. Analyzing the performance of a specific test or intervention should therefore include relevant parameters, such as adverse effects, costs, psychological impact, quality of life, and burden to individual patients and to society. In this case, data were complete and available for four outcomes of interest. Of these, routine care was not statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, but was superior in costs and not associated with complications, the more clinically relevant outcomes. Therefore, routine care can be recommended over both the experimental product and hypertonic saline.

Key learning point: Statistical significance does not equal clinical importance; interventions must be assessed by their real-world impact on patient-centered outcomes, costs, and adverse effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive, and hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician for advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect?


Approach
Relative risk
95% Confidence interval


A
0.78
0.71–0.86


B
0.74
0.37–0.99


C
0.82
0.75–1.2


D
1.2
1.1–1.4


E
1.3
1.0–1.4

choices.text: Approach E.
Approach C.
Approach B.
Approach A.
Approach D.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An RR > 1.0 indicates that the risk of recurrent urinary tract infection in the treatment group is higher than in the placebo group. In addition, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.

B) INCORRECT:

An RR < 1.0 indicates a protective effect of this intervention. However, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.

C) INCORRECT:

An RR < 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 suggests a protective effect for this intervention. However, the width of the CI is 0.37–0.99, indicating a relative risk reduction anywhere from 1–63%, which makes this a less precise estimate.

D) CORRECT:

The RR estimates the ratio of the probability of an outcome (e.g., recurrence of urinary tract infections) occurring in an exposed group (e.g., those receiving treatment) to the probability of the outcome occurring in an unexposed group (e.g., those receiving placebo). An RR < 1.0 indicates that a given treatment decreases the probability of an outcome. The CI provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. A CI that does not include 1.0 indicates a statistically significant difference between the two groups. Finally, the width of the CI provides information about the precision of the estimate. If the RR estimate is 0.78 and the CI is 0.71–0.86, the intervention likely has a protective effect, and the magnitude of that effect (relative risk reduction) could be anywhere from 14–29%. The narrower the CI, the more precise the RR estimate. Therefore, approach A has the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest CI).

Key learning point: Narrower 95% confidence intervals for relative risk estimates indicate increased precision, and intervals that don't include 1.0 suggest a statistically significant effect.

E) INCORRECT:

An RR > 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 indicates that this approach increases the risk of urinary tract infections rather than preventing their recurrence.
questions.hint: When evaluating a relative risk (RR) estimate, consider whether it is greater or less than 1.0. To evaluate a confidence interval (CI), consider whether it includes 1.0 and its width.

questions.text: Researchers are studying a novel cancer treatment in patients whose disease is refractory to conventional therapy. The study participants are randomized to one of two arms. Both arms receive the current standard of care; one arm also receives the new therapeutic agent, while the other arm receives placebo. The primary outcome in the study is the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two arms. Which of the following scenarios would constitute a type II error in this study?

choices.text: Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS.
Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS.
Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when appropriate hypothesis testing gives a p-value of 0.08.
Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS.
Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there was a difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was no difference constitutes a type I error.

B) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there is no PFS difference between the study groups when there truly is none (i.e., accepting a true null hypothesis) constitutes a correct interpretation of the results.

C) INCORRECT:

Concluding that there is a difference between the study groups when the p-value is >0.05 would not constitute a type I or type II error.

D) CORRECT:

A type II error is defined as the acceptance of a null hypothesis that is actually false. In this study, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in PFS between the two treatment groups. Therefore, concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in fact, the new drug prolongs PFS constitutes a type 2 error.

Key learning point: A type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis is accepted, concluding no effect when one truly exists.

E) INCORRECT:

Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in fact, it is longer with the new drug could occur from misreading the data or if an error occurred during data analysis, but this would not represent a type II error.

questions.text: Clinicians at a weight-loss clinic serving late adolescents and young adults are planning to investigate the average BMI of patients at the time they enroll in a program. They randomly select 150 patients and find that the mean BMI of this group was 36.2 at program enrollment. One of the clinicians asks if there is a way to measure whether the mean BMI in this patient sample is a precise measurement of the mean BMI in the larger clinic population. Which of the following measures would be most useful to answer this question?

choices.text: Standard error of the mean.
Median.
Standard deviation of the BMI measurement.
Power.
P-value.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The standard error of the mean (SEM) is a measure of dispersion used to assess the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean. In this case, the clinicians want to make inferences about the mean BMI of their clinic population based on their random sample. However, the mean BMI of the sample population is likely not identical to the mean BMI of the clinic population; if the clinicians chose other similarly sized samples, they would get slightly different mean BMIs. By repeatedly choosing different samples and calculating a sample mean each time, it becomes possible to calculate the standard deviation (SD) of those sample means, which is the SEM. The SEM can be estimated by dividing the sample SD by the square root of the sample size: SEM = SD / √(sample size). If either the sample size increases or the SD of the measurement decreases, then the SEM decreases and the precision increases.

Key learning point: The standard error of the mean (SD / √n) quantifies the precision of a sample mean in estimating the population mean.

B) INCORRECT:

A median is another measurement of central tendency and can be used instead of a mean in certain circumstances. It represents the middle value of a data set and does not allow any inferences regarding the population mean.

C) INCORRECT:

The standard deviation (SD) of the BMI measurement is an indication of the spread of the values around the mean. If there is a wide range of BMI values, then the SD will be large; if there is a narrow range, then the SD will be small. Although the SD is needed to calculate the measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean, it does not (on its own) allow for inferences about the population.

D) INCORRECT:

The power of a study is the probability that a test of significance will detect an effect that is present. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no power.

E) INCORRECT:

A p-value is calculated in hypothesis testing and indicates how incompatible the observed data may be with a null hypothesis. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no p-value.

questions.text: Researchers are studying a new diet and exercise intervention for weight loss. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms, an intervention arm and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach, and follow them for one year. At the end of the follow-up period, the average weight loss ± SD (standard deviation) is 14.1 kg ± 5.2 kg (31 lb ± 11 lb) for the intervention group and 10.3 kg ± 2.3 kg (23 lb ± 5 lb) for the standard-of-care group. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?

choices.text: All participants in the standard-of-care group had a weight change between –8.0 kg (18 lb) and +12.6 kg (28 lb) after one year.
Given a normal distribution of data, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss between 3.7 kg (9 lb) and 24.5 kg (53 lb) after one year.
Approximately 5.2% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss greater than the average compared with 2.3% of participants in the standard-of-care group.
Weight changes of greater than 2.3 kg (5 lb) or 5.2 kg (11 lb) after one year were considered significant in the standard-of-care and intervention groups, respectively.
The maximum amount of weight loss in the intervention group was 19.3 kg (42 lb) after one year.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

B) CORRECT:

In a normal distribution, two SDs above and below the mean cover ∼95% of the sample. Using the data from the study, we can therefore determine the range of weight loss experienced by 95% of the participants in the intervention group during one year of follow-up. The lower end of the range is found by subtracting two SDs from the mean: 14.1 - 2(5.2) = 3.7 kg (31 - 2(11) = 9 lb). The upper end of the range is found by adding two SDs to the mean: 14.1 + 2(5.2) = 24.5 kg (31 + 2(11) = 53 lb). Hence, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a one-year weight loss of between 3.7 kg and 24.5 kg (9 lb and 53 lb).

Key learning point: In a normal distribution, approximately 95% of values lie within two standard deviations above and below the mean, allowing estimation of the range that covers most participants’ outcomes.
Image Description:

Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.

Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.

(SD = standard deviation)

C) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

questions.text: A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89–2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1–2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate?

choices.text: The results of study B are less likely to be accurate than the results of study A.
The HR of study B is less likely to be statistically significant than the HR of study A.
Study A likely had a larger sample size than study B.
The p-value of study A is likely larger than the p-value of study B.
The power of study B is likely smaller than the power of study A.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accuracy refers to how well a study reflects the truth of the association between the variables of interest. It is impossible to make a statement about this study's accuracy without information regarding its methodology (e.g., inclusion/exclusion criteria, randomization strategy, group demographics), which would allow sources of systematic error to be properly evaluated.

B) INCORRECT:

Because the 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0 for study B but includes 1.0 for study A, it can be concluded that the HR for study B is statistically significant, while the HR for study A is not.

C) INCORRECT:

Assuming that all aspects of study design remain the same, a larger sample size (n) will decrease standard deviation, which results in a narrower confidence interval. Since study B has a narrower confidence interval than study A, it can be inferred that study B in fact had a larger sample size than study A. However, because no other information about the study populations is provided, it cannot be definitively concluded that this is the case.

D) CORRECT:

The 95% confidence interval of the HR for study A includes 1.0 and therefore is not statistically significant (p-value > 0.05). In contrast, the 95% confidence interval of the HR for study B does not include 1.0 and therefore is statistically significant (p-value < 0.05). Although the exact p-values are not given here, we can use this significance criterion to infer that (p-value of study B) < 0.05 < (p-value of study A).

E) INCORRECT:

Statistical power is increased by several factors, including large sample size, a large magnitude of effect between groups, increased precision of measurement, and the stringency of the statistical significance criterion chosen for the study (a p-value of 0.03 will fulfill a significance criterion of p < 0.05 before a significance criterion of p < 0.01). Because study B's 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0, this study had sufficient statistical power to detect a difference between the groups. In contrast, study A's 95% confidence interval of the HR includes 1.0; study A is therefore less powerful than study B.
questions.hint: A hazard ratio (HR) equal to 1.0 means there is no difference in the long-term VTE risk between the rheumatoid arthritis and control groups.

questions.text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of intranasal ketamine in decreasing acute suicidality in teenagers admitted to inpatient psychiatric units. They conducted a pilot study in which 15 participants were randomized to receive intranasal ketamine while 15 participants were randomized to receive a placebo. With the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators ultimately found no statistically significant difference in suicidality between the intervention and control groups after 30 days of follow-up. They suspect inadequate statistical power. Assuming the investigators intend to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following changes would be most effective to increase the statistical power?

choices.text: Decrease alpha
Decrease the sample size
Decrease the type II error rate
Increase beta
Increase the type I error rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreasing α (otherwise known as the type I error rate) is an aspect of experiment design that is intended to offset the risk of concluding that an effect or difference exists when there is, in fact, no effect or difference. The α is set by the researcher, with the most traditional value being 0.05. These researchers also used 0.05 (i.e., 5%) as the significance threshold. Changing this value will have no direct effect on the statistical power of the experiment.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreasing the sample size will cause a reduction in statistical power. A smaller sample is more subject to the effects of random chance, so the probability of committing a type II error will necessarily increase in this condition.

C) CORRECT:

Decreasing the type II error rate (symbolized as β) reduces the chance of accepting a false null hypothesis and rejecting a viable alternative hypothesis. Reducing β can be achieved by increasing the sample size in the study or by making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest. Either of these two actions will directly increase the statistical power. In mathematical terms, power = 1 – β so it easily follows that reducing β will lead to increased statistical power.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta, or the probability of a type II error, is the complement of power (power = 1 – β). Increasing β would cause a decrease in statistical power, the opposite of the desired effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing the type I error rate (also known as alpha), will have no direct effect on the statistical power. Alpha is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.
questions.hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).
